story:
To donate pick from the perks on the right side column or just give without perks. We also take pay pal!. 

Short Summary

Over the past year my team and I have been looking to do a project in Australia. I am excited to announce that we have touched base with local artists in Sydney who are thrilled to work with us. However, as with any event in another country, there are costs involved. I need your help getting there in order to fulfill this project and to help provide spaces for young artists to do the same!

This will be the fourth overseas art project and film the Antagonists have created in the last 8 years. From New York, Germany, Portugal, and Ecuador continue to work with and develop the artists we encountered on past projects. We couldn’t have made those trips possible without the help from our supporters via Kickstarter campaigns . Each project resulted in a feature documentary film that continues to help the artists involved. We try to provide venues for artists, mentoring, job placement, and exposure, and we hope—with your help—we can do it again. We have everything ready for this event, but we need your help in covering travel, accommodations, and final production costs to build the exhibition and workshops. With your support, we will expand our reach and discover new art and artists. 

What are we planning?

·  An art project titled “Dwelling.” In short, the project analyzes the feeling of safety in our homes, a safety that can be lost at a moments notice. International and local artists will  interpret this broad concept and express it through a variety of mediums including print, film making, and video mapping, to name a few.

·  A film screening of our past projects. This Is Berlin Not New York, The Dolls Of Lisbon and Self Medicated: A film about Art. These three project comprise a series of films about traveling artists and art projects. We hope Sydney can be the center of the next chapter.

Trailers of our past films and projects: 

For each of the following events we hope to collaborate with local artists.

·  Workshops: How to make a fanzine, working with textile design and various other themes. These will focus working with at-risk youth.


·  Writer’s night: 5 minutes to tell your best story. Introduction of local artists to global artists.

·  Portfolio review: We run our portfolio reviews a little differently. We aren't so much interested in giving critical feedback as we are in connecting artists with individuals and resources related to their work. If nothing else, we try to point them in a direction they hadn't thought about. 


We anticipate this project to take three weeks.

Who are we?

We travel and work on these projects as a family, which includes me, my wife Un Lee, my mother Judith E. McCaffrey, and Blu L. Minsker, my daughter. 

For this project I will be acting as head curator, filming the events, running the fanzine workshop, and hosting the screenings. Here is a little bio about me. 

Photo of Ethan by Simon Harsent.

Ethan H. Minsker is a writer, artist, and independent filmmaker. Minsker has written screenplays and produced and directed eight independent films. He is the founder of the Antagonist Movement, Inc., a consortium of artists, writers, and musicians based in New York's East Village. Minsker is also the creator and editor-in-chief of Psycho Moto Zine, in publication from 1988-present. He received his B.F.A. in Film with honors from the School of Visual Arts and his M.A. in Media from the New School. He resides in New York City.

Un Lee will be running the textile workshop and assisting the fanzine workshop. She will also be the assistant curator for the “Dwelling” show. 

Un Lee is a NY artist who draws, paints, illustrates, animates but mostly designs textiles.  She formed her textile/surface design company MADE BY UN in 2012 with clients ranging from Barnes and Noble to Walmart.  Un Lee graduated with a B.F.A. in Animation at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, then moved to Los Angeles and worked in many animated television series including Family Guy. 

For this project, Judith E. McCaffrey will be giving legal advice, coordinating  travel and lodging logistics, and assisting with planning, promoting, and organizing the events. Over the years she has been an active legal advisor and advocate for members of the group. She has done extensive public relations and guided us in setting up our not-for-profit.

After practicing law for a number of years in Washington, D.C., and then in Florida, Ms. McCaffrey permanently settled in New York City in 2004.  The focus of her practice is bank regulatory law, financial transactions, and corporate law. Before establishing her own firm in 1992, Ms. McCaffrey was a partner in a major law firm in Washington, D.C.  For eight years, she served as General Counsel of a $7.5 billion regional financial institution headquartered in Virginia.  Earlier in her career, Ms. McCaffrey was a Senior Counsel with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Ms. McCaffrey received her B.A. from Tufts University in 1966 and her law degree from Boston University in 1970.  Ms. McCaffrey is a member of the New York, Florida, D.C., and Massachusetts bar associations. She was president of the Washington D.C. Bar Association for Women.  If it’s not already clear, I am very proud of her.


What We Need & What You Get

It's awkward asking for help but it's essential to make this project happen. For your donation, you not only receive our sincerest gratitude, but you are also able to choose a reward, listed on the right side of this page. We have no problem taking donations without rewards but we have a host of special ones for this project. Books, films, shirts, original art, credit as a supporter in the next film, and more. We can't wait to send you some original artwork made by us for this project! Even more importantly, you'll help us build a new network of artists. I invite you to become a part of this exciting time for us. No donation amount is too little or too great. Please take a look at our IndieGoGo page for the list of donation options and reward choices.

How your donation will be used

1. Travel: We are hoping to offset travel costs. This is the biggest expense, about $2,500 for each of us, for a total of $10,000

2. Accommodations: $3,000 for 3 weeks.

3. Show production: $2,000 for the art show, $1,000 for workshops, screenings and everything else.

Anything beyond that the overflow will help offset the cost and burdens of our other invited artists. It would be fantastic to help bring artists from Europe.

The Impact

Taking 3 weeks off from work, adding the high cost of travel and renting a place for 3 weeks, food and extras, this project will leave us financially drained even if we do reach our goal. Based on our past excursions however, I know it’s worth it. The relationships and experiences change my perceptions of not just the world at large, but the limits of what I can do as an artist. The films have allowed me to share this with a larger audience. Your donation, your investment, and your trust is a vote of confidence that helps me succeed and lets me have an impact on others.

There is no way I, or the Antagonists, would be here today without the love and support of all of you and I want to thank you again from the bottom of my heart— you are making this possible for us and for that I am truly grateful.

Risks & Challenges

Traveling with artists to the other side of the world is never easy. We have found that you have to be flexible with local representatives. Things always change once you are on the ground. Weather, resources, and people can quickly dry up. Dealing with our own artists is like being a babysitter on steroids. Making a film about these projects is mentally and physically exhausting. While everyone else is having a good time, I am looking through the lens, trying to capture the moment.

However, we have now done this thrice before and are pros at dealing with unexpected changes—either way, the hardships makes for a fun film. The best results I find are when you are willing to work just a little bit harder to make your vision a reality. We’ve already pulled together the majority of the locations we need and found amazing people who have been willing to help us out with their time and their talents. Because we have built and opened exhibitions before, we are confident in our abilities to carry this project through to the end.

Not able to donate? You can still help!

We can't get around this fact: cash is what we need to make this happen. However, if you're not able to support the project financially, we hope that you'll share it with others and spread the word. Please share it if you donate, too. Please pass this on. Post it on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media. Make some noise! And of course, we hope that if you’re in Sydney, Australia during the show, you’ll come see the exhibit, films, and join the workshops!

You can use the Indiegogo share tools! [IndieGoGo link again]

Testimonials

“I worked with Ethan and the Antagonist Movement on two projects:

This is Berlin, Not New York (2008) in Berlin, Germany, and The Dolls of Lisbon (2011) in Lisbon, Portugal.

A vivid exchange on ideas and techniques, creating new contacts in cities around the world, and experiencing amazing art made those two projects into a huge success.

Ethan and his crew are very organized and enthusiastic about their projects.

I can highly recommend it to be part of the Antagonist Movement and I am really excited about the new “Dwelling” project in Australia.”

Jakob Theileis

artist

Berlin, Germany


"Hosting and working with the Antagonists was a very enriching experience. We learned a lot. We grew a lot. And we became part of a family. Might seem exaggerated but, in 2010, Lisbon was struggling with the beginning of a very severe economic crisis. The energy and actions provided by them [the Antagonists] provided us with a little more strength to keep up. Art is more than just concepts and objects, art is a full life experience."

Carlos Alcobia

Curator

Lisbon, Portugal


"I have worked with the Antagonists since 2009, from the time we had music and art shows in the back of a grungy bar. While our locations, artists, and shows have changed, the basic structure of the Antagonists will always remain—it is the glue—art for art’s sake. While we often create art for other sakes as well (community, enrichment, communication), that one crucial tenet is never forgotten, and it reminds us all that, first and foremost, art should be a love and a passion. The Antagonists take this love, and spread it throughout every community we visit, and in doing so, leave small breadcrumbs of ourselves sprinkled across the planet."

Marissa Bea

Antagonist Editor

New York City



PERKS!!!

Psycho Moto Zine was a periodical published from the late 1980s to early 2000s, consisting mostly of short stories, reviews and artwork. This fanzine would later birth the Antagonist Art Movement, a consortium of like-minded artists, writers, filmmakers, etc.

The magazine was originally published in 1989 under the name East Coast Exchange by Ethan H. Minsker. Copies were produced illicitly by friends who worked in copy shops during Minsker’s college years at School of Visual Arts in New York City and in Washington D.C. during Minsker’s summer breaks.

By 1994 Psycho Moto Zine (PMZ) had transformed into an arts and literary fanzine with reviews that covered underground art, fanzines, films and music. This connection between different creative elements was the inspiration for what would later become the Antagonist Art Movement.

story:
Project: Anthropomorphic Water V

My research aim to represent the natural human movement through liquid (watery) images. My research tools are contemporary dance and water macro photography. For this specific project I'm going to work with like-minded contemporary dancers who kindly offered to collaborate with me.

I have the chance to paint SAW wall in central Shoreditch, London. It's a big and central wall. I also would like to share this experience with friend artists who I respect a lot. The theme is play fighting in relationship.

I will ask the dancers to move as they feel and then experience gravity. The process will be done in solo and with interactions, where the play fighting will become the main theme.

The final result will be the wall, a making of and pictures of the dancers.

Hopefully we will all find more opportunities to work together on bigger and long-lasting project.

Thankfully we have the permission to paint the wall. The challenge will be to catch the interesting movements for my research and translate them in watery shapes. Play with light reflections and also try to be creative in an instinctive way. The size of the wall is very challenging, but this is also what I face everytime I need to paint a wall. I'm a professional mural artist. I will ask the help of people I truly respect to see how far we can get.

It's a big and central wall. I also would like to share this experience with friend artists who I respect a lot. The theme is play fighting in relationship.I will ask the dancers to move as they feel and then experience gravity. The process will be done in solo and with interactions, where the play fighting will become the main theme.The final result will be the wall, a making of and pictures of the dancers.Hopefully we will all find more opportunities to work together on bigger and long-lasting project.Thankfully we have the permission to paint the wall. The challenge will be to catch the interesting movements for my research and translate them in watery shapes. Play with light reflections and also try to be creative in an instinctive way. The size of the wall is very challenging, but this is also what I face everytime I need to paint a wall. I'm a professional mural artist. I will ask the help of people I truly respect to see how far we can get.

story:
HashFish emblems and t-shirts are the evolution of the Hasher* icon.
Hashers, members of the Hash House Harriers... "Drinkers with a running problem", are a unique breed, but a diverse group. Displaying a HashFish emblem on your vehicle or lanyard, or wearing a HashFish t-shirt will let the world know you're a Hasher, you only have half a mind, and you have bad taste... all of which are distinct qualities of a Hasher, through and through.


About Six O'Nine:
An entrepreneur since I was 6 years old (1973), a Hasher since 2001.
Owner of Envision Design and Deviant Liquid Latex since 1997.
I designed and have I've sold HashFish products to Hashers throughout North America since about 2002 and have hashed throughout North America.

Many, many people have been asking for HashFish during the last year, but when  personal and financial challenges caused me to lose almost everything (except my physical health), I didn't have the capital to produce more of these popular Hash icons.
Indiegogo.com is the funding solution to get you the HashFish you've wanted and help me generate a modest income and get back on my feet!

Thank you for your help and contribution.

   -Six

***************************************************************************


UPDATE:
Hashers, although my funding goal has been surpassed, it doesn't mean you can't still contribute to receive HashFish merchandise... In fact, thanks to the overwhelming support, EVERY CONTRIBUTOR WILL NOW GET A BONUS GIFT! Whether you've already contributed, or are still going to contribute, even for the smallest contribution will get an extra free bonus!

The extra funds being contributed will now allow me to produce products in higher volume and reduce my costs, so I'm including at least one extra bonus gift (maybe more) for EVERY SINGLE CONTRIBUTOR!

Thank you all so much! Please continue to help this Hasher out and keep the contributions coming... the more funds I receive, the more bonuses I'll send out!

On-on!
Six O'Nine﻿


***************************************************************************

*If you're not sure what a "Hasher" is, or who the "Hash House Harriers" are, take a look the these websites:

http://www.SVH3.com

http://www.SCH3.net/h3-history

http://www.Half-Mind.com

Cheers and On-On!

story:
The Museum of Science Fiction

MA-1 "Staff-Only" flight jacket



A new nonprofit is coming to Washington, DC

                                                

www.MuseumofScienceFiction.org


We're opening a preview location for the Museum of Science Fiction (MSF) as the first step to building a dedicated, comprehensive facility in Washington, DC! 

Through the preview museum, we can share our exciting vision with you, while at the same time building our collection and designing the full-scale museum. With your support, we can open the preview location as early as 2014.

Update 7 - New holiday gift perks announced! Signed copies of David Brin's new book Existence for $150, and full 3-day passes to Awesome Con for $130.  

Update 6 - David Brin wants to kill you or a loved one (in his next book) if you help the new Museum of Science Fiction!  That’s right, with a donation of $2,000, you can be immortalized as one of David’s characters in an upcoming science fiction novel by the award winning author!

Update 5 - The holiday season is just about upon us! Make a donation in honor of your loved one and we'll send you a certificate to commemorate your gift! Perks will arrive a few weeks after the campaign wraps in December.

Update 4 - Original Battlestar Galactica model used for filming is pledged for loan at the preview museum! The museum also announces a new partnership to save hundreds of historic sci-fi interviews - from Bradbury to Vonnegut to Clarke and more! 

Update 3 - Live panorama inspired by Blade Runner for the preview museum LED exhibit is released.

Update 2 - Executive Director of the Museum of Science Fiction hosts a Reddit AMA to answer your questions!  

Update 1 - Thanks to your incredible support the Museum sails past the $20k mark and recruits hundreds of volunteers!

To read all of the campaign updates in full, visit the updates section here.


See behind the scenes footage from our commercial video shoot with Star Wars characters at the U.S. Capitol!

The preview museum will become a center for science fiction fans and enthusiasts, in the heart of one of the world's greatest cities. In the space, we will hold our first public lectures, education programs, film screenings, book signings, and special events. And you're invited to join our project.

The preview location will also house the museum's first collection of artifacts from film, television, literature, and art, along with prototypes from the museum's model shop.  

Preview museum architectural rendering by Imarchination.

It's here that we'll test new concepts, create exhibits, and experiment with technologies like augmented reality to give you the ultimate future-oriented visitor experience. We want this museum to be at the leading edge of imagination and technology. 

Already, a number of artifacts have been pledged for loan to the preview museum by renowned science fiction artifact collector Adam Schneider and the eminent art collectors Howard and Jane Frank. These artifacts will fill the preview space along with the elements shown in the layout concepts below.


Note: We are a certified non-profit organization incorporated in the District of Columbia.  We will be transmitting information to all of our donors on tax deductibility for their charitable contributions according to IRS guidelines.


The preview museum will have a 3,000 square-foot open floor plan with two major exhibit pieces made exclusively for the museum by Color-Ad, a premier museum design and construction firm. When you enter the space, an 11-foot starship Enterprise-E filming prop will be the first artifact you see next to an iconic Doctor Who TARDIS police box.



Opposite the art exhibit space, gaze upon incredible panoramic vistas of far away worlds that we'll create with a huge floor-to-ceiling LED screen. We want you to feel immersed in the visions of science fiction, so we're installing a high-resolution media system by Traxon Techologies that features unprecedented clarity.

For example, imagine watching this panorama of Los Angeles inspired by Blade Runner on the preview location’s wall-size LED!  Made exclusively by David Glicksman of Applied Esoterics in Los Angeles for use in the Museum of Science Fiction preview location, this panorama gives you an exciting idea of the landscapes that could be brought to life if we reach our goal.  


The open floor plan also will also include a coffee and espresso bar, so you can sip a favorite drink while looking upon the captivating views of Cloud City, Pandora, Jurassic Park, and other well-known science fiction vistas. This could become you're favorite meeting place, or just a spot for a weekday inspiration break. 

By evening, the preview museum will convert to a venue. We will be able to host all manner of events. You can join us for a film, a lecture, or an award ceremony.

The architectural firm Imarchination has been helping us design a space that is both innovative and multipurpose. The firm is leading the design of the preview museum and they are full of exciting ideas. Here's a look at their notional plans:

Commercial real estate advisory firm Newmark Grubb Knight Frank is working with us to find the ideal site for the preview museum, with a focus on securing a highly visible location accessible to the 50,000 visitors who come to Washington, DC each day.

 

With your help the action begins now, and we can open the preview museum in 2014. By reaching our fundraising goal, we can start to build exhibits, secure real estate, renovate a facility, transport artifacts, and build display fixtures.

  • Building, Transporting, and Setting Up Exhibits: Although we've got several key artifacts already lined up, we still have to build the Doctor Who TARDIS, along with support structures for the 11-foot Enterprise-E filming prop. We're constructing exhibit structures for the remaining pledged artifacts named above, including display fixtures for the Frank Art Collection. We're also building interactive kiosks throughout the space to enhance the level of visitor experience.

    Unique museum objects call for special transportation and care. Almost half the money we hope to raise will fund the safe delivery to and careful installation of artifacts, art, and other display objects. We will work with only the best partner companies to complete these particular tasks, and we are lining up special agreements needed to do so. In the preview facility, these objects will be installed for maximum visual impact, whether in display cases or mounted on the ceiling or walls.
  • Selecting the Space: With the help of local firms and volunteers, we’ve already begun the site selection process, project planning, and architectural design work. Now is the time to integrate these efforts and take the next steps by picking a space in downtown Washington, DC. With your help, we'll be able to make firm commitments and start building the preview museum.
  • Renovating the Space: While we hope to find a space that meets as many of our requirements as possible, chances are we’ll need to renovate a bit: knock out walls; install proper lighting; and widen doorways so we can easily move big objects in and out of the space. These are some of the basic and essential renovations we expect to make.

This museum is beginning with a strong grassroots commitment by a group of science fiction fans. That's why a lot of our perks give you exclusive access and input to the decision making behind the museum. From webcasts with staff, to surveys, to official fan advisory panels — pledge now and voice your opinions.

We also have a number of first-edition museum collectibles, along with many items that will grow your science fiction collections. Here are some of our featured perks:

With a $25 pledge, you'll receive a beautiful digital certificate designed by the Chief Curator Phil Smith. This certificate certifies your status as a museum Founding Colonist. You'll also receive the Founding Colonist Kit, which includes the digital version of the original Museum of Science Fiction 2013 Planning Document — describing our plans and milestones in detail, how the galleries and exhibits will be designed, and who is involved. Also includes a one-year subscription to the MSF Quarterly Newsletter to keep you informed on our progress. Your name will also appear in rotation in the preview museum on our LED screen, along with our "Founding Colonists" webpage (only with your permission).

Get the first-edition Museum of Science Fiction collectibles! Includes the museum magnet — perfect for a filing cabinet, fridge, car, or airlock door. You also get the first-edition museum mug, which we're told may work in zero-g, but no promises. Your name will also be added to the LED screen and you'll get the Founding Colonist Certificate and the Founding Colonist Kit.

Get electronic access to every book saved by Singularity & Co., preservers of science fiction, fantasy, and vintage pulp for one full year. Plus, access to other exciting SaveTheScifi.com member benefits. You'll also receive the exhibits input survey, your name will be added to the LED screen, and you'll get the Founding Colonist Certificate and the Founding Colonist Kit.

A limited-edition signed and numbered fine-art print by artist and museum Chief Curator Phil Smith. Choose from two options, both 8”x10” prints. Also includes access to the exclusive webcast by a senior museum staff member, where you can provide input and ask questions. You'll receive the exhibits input survey, your name will be added to the LED screen, the Founding Colonist Certificate, and the Founding Colonist Kit.


Get all three sci-fi classics on DVD: 2001: A Space Odyssey, Jurassic Park, and Blade Runner: The Final Cut. Also includes the first edition museum t-shirt, and access to an exclusive webcast by a senior museum staff member, where you can provide input and ask questions. You'll receive the exhibits input survey, your name will be added to the LED screen, the Founding Colonist Certificate, and the Founding Colonist Kit.

Meet award winning science fiction author Greg Bear at a private lecture in the preview museum and get a signed hardcover copy of “Hull Zero Three.” Also includes a private tour of the preview museum and access to an exclusive webcast by a senior museum staff member, where you can provide input and ask questions. You'll receive the exhibits input survey, the Founding Colonist Certificate, the Founding Colonist Kit and your name will be added to the LED screen.


*Please note: International shipping requires additional charges.  Please consider adding $10 to your pledge if you choose a perk that will be shipped to a destination outside of the United States.


The Museum of Science Fiction will be the world’s first comprehensive science fiction museum, covering the history of the genre across the arts and providing a narrative on its relationship to the real world. Our mission is to be a center of gravity where art and science are powered by imagination.

  • ART: MSF will be a repository of science fiction art throughout the ages, covering centuries of literature, paintings, sculpture, scale models, film, and music. Art is what we create for aesthetic and contemplative consideration. 
  • SCIENCE: MSF will show the connections between science fiction and science fact, demonstrating how art can play a role in inspiring scientific investigations and how scientific discovery can inspire art. Science is the systematic and organized body of knowledge shared across cultures and time in a manner that can be tested and verified. 
  • IMAGINATION: MSF will be a cathedral of imagination, a place to celebrate the unique human characteristic of conceiving new solutions to problems, new stories, and new ideas. This is the aspect of expanding beyond all that we know. 

We are taking an incremental approach to building the Museum of Science Fiction by starting with a preview location. This proven approach  has worked well for many other successful museums. The preview location is step one in our comprehensive and measured plan to make the full-scale museum a reality.  

First, science fiction needs a permanent home. The museum will fill a need to house historically important artifacts that is currently unmet by existing institutions. The museum will also provide a permanent center for the science fiction community and culture.

Second, science fiction motivates learning. At the museum, we will engage children and young adults with a variety of exhibits and programs designed to interest them in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our education staff will collaborate with educators and school boards early in the planning phase of programs to make sure our programming supports their plans.


Third, science fiction inspires imagination. STEM skills are important, but they are just part of what's needed to drive innovation. The Museum of Science Fiction has the potential to motivate students to pursue not only STEM fields, but also the arts, and develop the curiosity and imagination needed for innovative thinking and creative problem solving.

The Museum of Science Fiction will feature artifacts covering a wide range of subjects, arrayed in an immersive manner so that visitors are absorbed by the wonder of human imagination. 

We will draw artifacts from art (literature, fine art, illustration, industrial design, film, television, music, and dance), science, and engineering disciplines. At the museum, you will learn how art has inspired and informed science and engineering, as well as how science and engineering have informed art.

We are designing a walk path and features for each gallery that will encourage curiosity and learning. Our permanent collection will include galleries, divided into exhibits, and arranged according to seven themes, presented below. 


Upon entering the museum, the visitor will learn about the definition of science fiction. It will become immediately apparent that there are many definitions, even among science fiction authors, literary experts, and filmmakers; however, the common thread is exploring of the impact of science and technology on society through fictional stories. +MORE



This gallery will capture the settings of science fiction stories. Naturally, the settings vary greatly, but often include alien planets, alternate versions of Earth, or Earth itself in the past, present, or future. Sometimes the setting is galactic or extragalactic, but it may also be limited to a city—or even be microscopic in scale. +MORE



More often than not, science fiction stories depend on some sort of transportation, whereby characters move between locations in a story. These vehicles sometimes become characters in themselves, not unlike how a seagoing vessel is conceived as a contributing personality by members of the crew. +MORE



Most people conceive of time as a linear construct. In reality, it is an integral part of the universe, a fourth dimension along with the three spatial dimensions. Some cultures perceive time as circular, so that it does not have a beginning or an end. This gallery will explore how time is manipulated as part of the story, beginning with a display that describes what time is, special relativity, and other considerations. +MORE



There's more to life in science fiction than aliens — although this gallery will cover alien life in detail. Science fiction also explores genetic engineering, body modification, diseases, and — in an obvious merging with Computers & Robots — biomechanical organisms. In some instances, science fiction dealing with human modification results in a sub-genre called "body horror." +MORE



By the 20th century, and especially following the invention of the computer during World War II, the idea of smart computers and sophisticated human-like robots emerged. Typically, science fiction stories that include these artificial organisms explore themes relating to technologies run amok, the ethics of creating an artificial intelligence, robotic warriors, computers that interpret commands in unpredictable ways (with negative consequences for humans), and robots or androids as everyday companions. +MORE



This gallery will be home to all the tools conceived as supporting elements in science fiction stories that are not represented in the other galleries. These exhibits will feature speculative technologies that deserve recognition in part because they influence today’s technology or may influence technological development in the future. +MORE


Share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, in email, blogs, phone calls, or holograms with family, friends, colleagues, Trekkies, Whovians, Browncoats, Star Wars fans, nerds, geeks, techies, futurists, fans of Avatar, Back to the Future, Alien, Stargate, Battlestar Galactica...and anyone who drives a DeLorean.

When the preview museum opens, we'll need volunteers to take on a number of important roles — including docent positions. Click here to sign up and be added to the volunteer list. 

Do you have an item you think should be in the Museum of Science Fiction? We're accepting artifacts and display objects for loan or donation. Click here to contact us.

It will become immediately apparent that there are many definitions, even among science fiction authors, literary experts, and filmmakers; however, the common thread is exploring of the impact of science and technology on society through fictional stories. +MORE

This gallery will capture the settings of science fiction stories. Naturally, the settings vary greatly, but often include alien planets, alternate versions of Earth, or Earth itself in the past, present, or future. Sometimes the setting is galactic or extragalactic, but it may also be limited to a city—or even be microscopic in scale. +MORE

More often than not, science fiction stories depend on some sort of transportation, whereby characters move between locations in a story. These vehicles sometimes become characters in themselves, not unlike how a seagoing vessel is conceived as a contributing personality by members of the crew. +MORE

Most people conceive of time as a linear construct. In reality, it is an integral part of the universe, a fourth dimension along with the three spatial dimensions. Some cultures perceive time as circular, so that it does not have a beginning or an end. This gallery will explore how time is manipulated as part of the story, beginning with a display that describes what time is, special relativity, and other considerations. +MORE


There's more to life in science fiction than aliens — although this gallery will cover alien life in detail. Science fiction also explores genetic engineering, body modification, diseases, and — in an obvious merging with Computers & Robots — biomechanical organisms. In some instances, science fiction dealing with human modification results in a sub-genre called "body horror." +MORE


By the 20th century, and especially following the invention of the computer during World War II, the idea of smart computers and sophisticated human-like robots emerged. Typically, science fiction stories that include these artificial organisms explore themes relating to technologies run amok, the ethics of creating an artificial intelligence, robotic warriors, computers that interpret commands in unpredictable ways (with negative consequences for humans), and robots or androids as everyday companions. +MORE


This gallery will be home to all the tools conceived as supporting elements in science fiction stories that are not represented in the other galleries. These exhibits will feature speculative technologies that deserve recognition in part because they influence today’s technology or may influence technological development in the future. +MORE




Share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, in email, blogs, phone calls, or holograms with family, friends, colleagues, Trekkies, Whovians, Browncoats, Star Wars fans, nerds, geeks, techies, futurists, fans of Avatar, Back to the Future, Alien, Stargate, Battlestar Galactica...and anyone who drives a DeLorean.

When the preview museum opens, we'll need volunteers to take on a number of important roles — including docent positions. Click here to sign up and be added to the volunteer list. 


Do you have an item you think should be in the Museum of Science Fiction? We're accepting artifacts and display objects for loan or donation. Click here to contact us.

story:
Welcome, welcome, welcome Puffers!  You have just stepped into the world of our newest Art Project!  Every year, we sit there and watch the big kids ride out of camp to deep Playa on their art cars, while we have sat around in camp since we lost the flying saucer.  This year, with the help of many people in Denver, some virgins with some very good skill sets, and the determination by a couple of our old crusty veterans, we will be presenting to you our solution to this problem.  For those of you who have been following the story so far, we have prepared a workspace and purchased a platform.  This project will take contributions from our WHOLE BPY FAMILY.  After many years of doing this, we know that projects like this cannot be finished without everyone's contribution.  "It ain't gonna Puff itself!!!" .  For the long and short of it, the Denver crew is going to build this and we need the international family to fund it.  This takes a massive amount of time and energy to create this kind of an art project. 

This plan involves several stages of construction.  We have finished the initial deconstruction, and are preparing to build the main steel structure.  Along with this build and this phase of production, we will be rebuilding the engine and replacing all six tires to develop a car that is Playa-ready.  Second stage will involve decoration, audio and sound installation, along with lighting.  Third stage will be finishing touches, deconstruction and packing for transport, and delivery to the Playa.  All of this, will of course not be cheap; two fundraisers will be conducted to get it there.  We need your support!  Please pass this to anyone you know going to the Playa or extended BPY family, and anyone that supports this kind of art.  This car will be a people-mover and camp art car, not a personal transport vehicle.  We need you, the people, to make this happen. 

Thanks E-rock & Rickey Bobby

story:
Who are the Geishas?

The hosts at Geisha House have been providing a fur & velvet lined sanctuary with free flowing sake and a friendly welcoming vibe on the Playa, for over a decade.  For Burning Man 2012, the Geisha's have an ambitious goal of building their first Mutant Vehicle. 

Our goal: Create a beautiful, functional Interactive Art Experience, that everyone and anyone can enjoy. 

Why we need your help

The majority of funding for this project is provided by the Geisha's themsevles. Our total budget for this project is a whopping $15,000.00.

1999.00 will contribute to cost related to transport of Cloud 9 and fuel on/off the Playa. 

The costs for the car, the materials to build it/pimp it out, the workshop/tools, the time, effort and love invested in building Cloud 9 is largely being donated by the Geisha's themselves. 

Why, why, and why? 

Frankly, Black Rock City needs more Art Cars. So, we're building one. A pretty  freakin' awesome one, at that. 

Also - Cloud 9 is a our vehicle to flex our skills at: 

  • Creativity - building Art at any age is good for the Universe
  • Collaboration - it's a large complicated project, we build it together
  • Generosity & Sharing - Cloud 9 is for everyone to enjoy
  • Whimsy - You are never too old for a solid dose of whimsy

Thanks for your support. See you at Black Rock!

story:
Give me a dollar!

So the basic idea here is you hopefully have many dollars, through this site you please give me one of them (or more if you'd like) and then I will use that dollar to help fund my passion, stand-up comedy.
 
Making a living as a local, unknown stand up comic is hard due to low pay scales and other local, unknown stand up comics willing to work for less.  While pursuing my dream, I forgot to have a back up plan as far as an other career or an education to fall back on, so I developed a plan where I start this page and you help me pay off debt and pay utilities (not just spend it on booze) by giving me a dollar.  Hopefully this adds up to many dollars, yet still costs you only one.  
 
You may think, what I great idea, I would love to contribute more than one dollar!  Feel free!  I have put together a few silly, small "perks" and the person who contributes the highest donation will be mentioned by name on stage at my monthly show at the Comedy Studio on November 25th, when I talk about the results of this campaign. 
 
Thanks!  Let's have fun.  Also give me a dollar...

story:
Hi!

The short story - Cool nude figure letters turned into fun fridge art!  Now read on if you're intrigued :)

I’m a fine art photographer that focuses on the human figure.  Rather than classic poses, I like to explore unique geometric poses and quirky presentation (My video describes my work in general, not this project specifically).  Recently, I took my love of figure photography and started a project called Body Language.  The fruits of this project are on display through the end of June at Washington DC’s largest art show, Artomatic.

An example of one of the images below.

In this instance, the subject is a traveling model who never stays in one place more than a few short weeks.  She yearns to move and see new things.  Thus, the word that she felt was her Body Language is “Wanderlust”

Body Language focuses on the right to freedom of expression which is an extension of the right to freedom of speech guaranteed by the First Amendment of the US constitution.  It merges the two by spelling expressive words using the nude figure.  As a central theme, I wrote out the first few lines of the First Amendment using the nude figure

In looking for a way for the viewer to interact with the display, the idea of nude letter magnets was born. (all credit to my wife!)

Body Language Letter Magnets is a set of magnetic letters created with the nude form.  The set will contain 100 1in by 1in letter magnets allowing short phrases to be spelled out.  Each letter is a unique piece of fine art photography, and no two letters in each set are alike.  Any word or phrase you create will be a unique statement of your own coupled with a statement of your right to freedom of expression.  I created a prototype for the Artomatic display, and have had great feedback and lots of viewer participation.

Think of how much fun it will be at parties!

My modest funding goal is based on the initial start up costs associated with hiring models specifically for this project, initial die costs for printing the magnets, and other assets required to get the series going.  It also includes the first bulk production run, which is required to keep the individual prices down.  My hope is that once these are in place, the project will be self sustaining through sales.  I have future plans to release sets that feature the male nude (the initial run will be female due to the results of a market survey) as well as other related products (don’t want to tip my hand :)

Your pledge to support this project will help develop a fun art product that promotes free speech and expression as well as demonstrates your love of the arts.

If the project doesn't get fully funded, I'll continue to look for funding until I have what I need to produce the set and then send the sets to those who've pledged the amount that gets them a free set.  Folks who've pledged amounts that get more than the set will get the prints right away, and the sets when they are produced.  Anyone you pledges will have access to the wallpaper.  The reason I didn't set this up as a fixed funded project is that if the goal isn't met, the thrid party fees aren't refunded!

Thank you for your support!

Rahul

www.eyeofraphoto.com

story:
A design collective for Beirut

The blast that rocked Beirut on August 4 resulted in more than 177 fatalities, 6000 injuries, with an estimated 300,000 people left homeless. The scale of the blast is unlike anything Beirut had seen in its turbulent history and Lebanon is already suffering from near economic collapse, a banking and currency crisis, and the pandemic. To show support and solidarity for the people of Beirut, the international type design community has come together to create a typeface that would raise funds to support the victims of the blast and the reconstruction efforts.

 

The heart of this campaign

Curated by Lebanese designer Dr. Nadine Chahine, the typeface Li Beirut has more than 300 glyphs drawn by 157 designers from all around the world. Among the contributors are award winning designers such as Jean-François Porchez, Jessica Hische, Erik Spiekermann, Martina Flor, Tobias Frere-Jones, Hannes von Doehren, Erin McLaughlin, Erik van Blokland, Petr van Blokland,  Martin Majoor, Neil Summerour, Toshi Omagari, and David Berlow. Arabic designers include Mamoun Sakkal, Bahia Shehab, Pascal Zoghbi, Khajag Apelian, Wael Morcos, Yara Khoury, Kristyan Sarkis, and Maha Akl.

The font includes decorative isolated Arabic letters and Latin capitals as well as Arabic numerals and a few symbols, all in one font file, together symbolising the solidarity of the international community with Beirut and its people.

  • By supporting this campaign you will get a working font with over 300 decorative glyphs and the option to acquire a set of catalogue and postcards printed in Beirut.
  • You can use this font in your own projects, and the word combinations are simply gorgeous!
  • All profit raised will go towards charities supporting the victims and the reconstruction efforts. I have chosen reputable ones that are collecting funds for Beirut efforts and work in Lebanon either directly or through local partners: 

    Plan International: https://plan-uk.org/emergencies/beirut-emergenc...

    Action Against Hunger: https://www.actionagainsthunger.org.uk/beirut-e...

    and Save The Children: https://www.savethechildren.org.uk/how-you-can-...

 

Design that can heal

The type design community has shown amazing solidarity, coming together in the span of just one week, to contribute these brilliant designs. This is what good design can do.

  • The Lebanese people are suffering from massive financial difficulties with 50% of the population now under the poverty line. Small businesses are under strain, especially given the pandemic, and now with the blast many people are destitute. Your valuable contribution can help lighten that burden.
  • A few years back campaign founder Dr. Nadine Chahine raised $22,170 for the family of Georges Al-Reef whose brutal murder had shocked Lebanon. Today she hopes to support many more families in her hometown Beirut.
  • The contributing designers wrote many messages of hope and the overwhelming sentiment was a message to the people of Beirut: you are not alone, and we are with you. By contributing to this campaign, you are sending that message too.

 

Printed in Beirut, shipped to you worldwide

The financial difficulties that Lebanon is going through has put incredible strains on local businesses. We help them get back on their feet when we engage their business. To that end, the campaign includes printed goods that will be printed at Karaky Printing Press in Beirut, and shipped to you wherever you are. There are some implications to this:

  • Shipping costs are significant. It might have been easier to just print in the UK, but it meant a lot to be able to print at home, and for people around the world to get postcards that say: printed in Beirut. This way we show support to local businesses, and send the message that no matter what happens, Beirut carries on, and its renowned presses will not stop. Not for war, and not for explosions. Beirut lives on. 
  • The financial hurdles for sending money to Lebanese charities are many, given the banking crisis, and the imminent lockdown due to Covid-19. The campaign will continue to vet different routes to overcome that and consult with tax advisers for best possible avenues. We will post regular updates on the progress.

 

Letters of hope

If you are not able to contribute, there are other ways you can help:

  • Check out our Instagram and Twitter account @FontLiBeirut and help us spread the word! Let us spread these letters of hope as far and as wide as possible!
  • Tell your friends and family about our campaign, and keep Beirut and its people in your thoughts...

 

Our design community

A million thanks to the contributors without whom this would not be possible: Abdo Hassanine, Abdo Mohamed, Abdullah Arif, Alja Herlah, Alja Herlah, Amélie Bonet, Amina Tayyub, Amjad Alobaidi, Anagha Narayanan, Ann Bessemans, Antonio Pace, Atea Porchez, Azza Alameddine, Bahia Shehab, Bernd Volmer, Cecilia del Castillo Daza, Chank Diesel, Chris Lozos, Christine Zaghloul, Craig Eliason, Dave Coleman, David Berlow, David Williams, Dino dos Santos, Ebin Sorkin, Eduardo Tunni, Ehab Elhamzawy, Eli Heuer, Erik Moberg, Erik Spiekermann, Erik van Blokland, Erika Georgina Mendoza, Erin McLaughlin, Eyass Elkadi, Fadi kassab, Farah Al- Adawy  , Fedwa Snoussi, Florian Parmentier, Foad Aramrad, Francisco Torres, Garine Gokceyan, Gina Serret Jové, Grant Hutchinson, Greta Khoury, Habiba Elgendy, Haitham Almayman, Hala Asfsaa, Hannes von Döhren, Hareem Farrukh, Henrik Birkvig, Ingy Fawzy, Irina Koryagina, Jacques Le Bailly, Jason Campbell, Jean-Françoir Porchez, Jeff Kellem, Jeppe Pendrup, Jessica Hische, Joel Mitchell, John Downer, Jordan Bell, Juanjo Lopez, June Shin, Justin Penner, Kaja Słojewska, Karim Joreige, Ken Barber, Kevin Adams, Khajag Apelian, Khaled Sawaf, Kinda Ghannoum, Kristyan Sarkis, Lara Captan, Laura Serra, Lazydogs Typefoundry, Letterjuice, Lila Symons, Lisa Maione, Lynn Yun, Maha Akl, Mahmoud Abd El-Ghany, Mamoun Sakkal, Marie Boulanger, Mark Simonson, Martin Majoor, Martin Silvertant, Martin Wenzel, Martina Flor, Marty Gotera, Marwa Gadallah, Mathieu Reguer, Max Phillips, Maximilian Bergmann, Maya Rizkallah, Mike Duggan, Mirko Velimirovic, Muhammad Reza Rizky, Muiz, Muna Abdelhadi, Murad Alshawareb, Nadine Chahine, Najla M. Badran, Neil Summerour, Neva Zidic, Nijad Abdelsamad, Nika Langosz, Nikolay Petroussenko, Nina Stoessinger, Nisrine Fayad, Nisrine Sarkis, Nouf Rashid, Nour Alshamy, Omaima Dajani, Ondrej Jób, Osama Shormani, Pascal Zoghbi, Paul Hanslow, Petr van Blokland, Pria Ravichandran, qassim haider, Quentin Schmerber, Rachael Miller, Rana Elgohary, Rania Baltagi, Rania Nader Bechara, Raphaël Ronot, Razan Basim, Riccardo Sartori, Ro Hernandez, Ruggero Gualdesi, Rutherford Craze, Sabina Chipară, Sally Mallat, Samar Zureik, Sami Khaled, Sanskriti Dholi, Sara Jamshidi, Sara Soskolne, Sarah Shebl, Sebastian Losch, Shahd Asabagh, Sheikah Essam, Simon Thiefes, Sophia Tai, Stéphane Elbaz, Stephen Nixon, Thibaut Abou Mrad, Thierry Blancpain, Tiffany Wardle, Tobias Frere-Jones, Tom Grace, Torben Wilhelmsen, Toshi Omagari, Wael Morcos, Yara Khoury, Yesha Goshar, Yorlmar Campos, Zainab AlShibani, Zeina Ghosn, and Zenab Bastawala.

 

Thank you all so much!

story:
Glass Can Be Alive

My name is Ksenija Djurica, I live in Belgrade and I am a graphic designer.
Currently, my hobby is making glass beeds using the lampwork technique, by melting glass with flame. Out of these beeds I make jewellery. 

Some of you may be wondering what is interesting about that?

You know, I have always loved making something with my hands, but I have never had enough time, at least not as much as I wanted to. Throughout the years, I have painted, sculptured and I have graduated from Art Academy.

The years were passing, and I was increasingly missing that kind of creative expression. I have to stress out that i work as graphic designer, but since that is a job that only consists of working on the computer, you can assume that is not the same kind of creativity.

Creativity... I simply long for it.

You Make My Dream Come True

My dream is that one day I become an artist who makes glass beads, have my own studio and perfect this kind of art.

Also I hope that this campaign will help me that one day I can teach young people from Serbia who would like to experience the beauty of glass moulding .
Currently in Serbia there is not an artist who would pass on his knowledge and experience in working with glass.

$1, $2, $3...

With this campaign I would like to collect money which I need primarily to enhance my tools and therefore my work.

First thing I need is a better torch, gas equipment, modeling tools and plenty of various glass. In case I don’t achieve my goal I hope that I will collect enough money for the new torch at least.

My greatest joy is seeing people happy when I hand them my beads. It really fulfills me.
I am happy that my little artistic handicrafts beautify people all over the world.
I want to give my beeds to you, as well.

Any kind of help is more than welcome. Please share this link, like my facebook page... make a donation and in return I will send you my beads, I will send you a piece of me.

"A piece of art must grip you, draw you in and take you far away. It is a means which an artist uses to convey his passion…"
                                                                                                                          - Renoir -

______________________________________________________________________________

Pledge $1 or more - Every dollar counts! My sincere gratitude and thanks! You will receive acknowledgements on your website or your email together with a photo of my bead in high resolution for print or for your desktop.


FAQ

Who and where made this glass beads?
All beads and jewerly on the photos I made in my home-studio in Belgrade.

Where can I look your other work?
You can check my other work at:
https://www.facebook.com/SvetStaklenihPerli

Which glass are beads made of?
In making my glass beads I use soft glass 104COE Murano and Reichenbach 104.

Are this glass beads easy to break?
Glass beads are very resistant because after melting they annealed in a digitally-controlled kiln  for durability.

What is difference beetwen 925 silver and silver plated jewerly?
Sterling silver or silver 925 is an alloy of silver containing 92.5% by mass of silver and 7.5% by mass of other metals. A silver plated jewelry has basically another metal coated with a thin layer of silver on the surface.

Why is the shipping free?
That is my present to the funders.

Will I get the jewerly which is on the pictures?
No. In the pictures are shown only samples. Jewerly which I am going to send as gift, is going to be made during the campaign and after the end of campaign. Every bead is small piece of art, and art cant be multiply. I make only unique.

How can I help in the campaign?
Beside donating I would be very thankful if you like my facebook page
https://www.facebook.com/SvetStaklenihPerli
and to share link to toward my campaign to your friends
http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/world-of-glass-beads

Thank you, I wish you lots of love
Yours
Ksenija Djurica

story:
Arts in the Alley is a community project in Richmond VA to turn rundown city streets and alleys into bright outdoor art galleries by painting murals.

Our next project is the weekend of April 27-28. We will be painting five murals in the Richond neighborhood of Jackson Ward. We just found out our resource for scaffolding fell through (some of our murals are quite tall). We have a few donations we know will be coming in, but we still need to raise an additional $1000 by April 27.

So: this is an emergency campaign.... can you help us? If we have 50 people who can spare $20 we have what we need. Or 10 people who give $100. Or 100 people who can contribute $10. You get the idea. Can you help us?

Creating a brighter future,

Jeanine Guidry

Executive Director, Arts in the Alley

 

P.S. The video attached is from one of our earlier projects - but gives you a good idea of the work we do!

story:
Please back our MANTRA Indiegogo campaign!

"Your first step extends your purpose to find peace, health & happiness." - 

Ronnie C. Wright

  • In September 2011, Ronnie C. Wright became the first person to record a 100 mile solo walk from Beverly Hills to Ojai, California.
  • Please help us spread the word about our Indiegogo "Art Health" campaign for MANTRA, a book & exhibition of black and white photographs focused on "Silent Partners" - those little things we often take for granted, inspired by Ronnie C. Wright's historic walk.
  • As a contributor - you will help us achieve a campaign focused on spreading the value of health - sustained & enhanced with art.


What We Need

  • Help us spread "Art-Health" to inspire people to take that first step to stay 'Fit.Intelligent.Natural.Energetic.'
  • The funds go to producing FREE seminars and events for MANTRA - Moving Audiences Naturally Through Art.

The Impact

  • This project is valuable because it contributes to a better world through health...
  • Ronnie C. Wright is the author of 15 books and President of the Fine Fitness Foundation dedicated to "HEALTH" - Helping Every Age Live Today Healthy.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute then still help:

  • Please get the word out!

story:
LÊSTRADA FREE ART FESTIVAL 

  • Art exhibitions, workshops, perfomances, talks and shows 
  • Date and Local: 13 to 21 of August, 2016. / Forum Landi e Praça do Carmo (Belém - Pará - Brasil)
  • Festival Activities:
    • 13 and 14: Opening of the exhibitions, workshops at Forum Landi and Open Air live acts.
    • 15 to 19: Exhibitions in Forum Landi, talks and workshops.
    • 20 and 21: Exhibition with the final result of the workshops, closing day of the exhibitions at Forum Landi and Open Air live acts. 

  • The Collective
We exist as an art and affection family called LÊSTRADA COLETIVX and we are composed by street artists, independent cultural producers, musicians, illustrators, painters, graphic designers, writers and media activists. We have the interest in researching and developing projects that dialogue with multiple interfaces of art languages through a hybrid and organic movement of construction. Inside of us, coexist the desire of understanding how could we achieve a creative, plural, critic and collective thought about the possibilities of the independent art production, the cultural scene from each place, the position of the hybrid artist and it’s connections in between the multiple formats of creating art. Nowadays we are immerse in Rio de Janeiro, executing an art school exchange at the School of Visual Arts of Parque Lage. Beyond the exchange with the new environment and the dive inside the particular universe of each one of us (including living at the same house), we are preparing ourselves and getting our experience together to explode in the second semester in Belém. Our first activity will be the Lêstrada Free Art Festival as a result of our productions and the achievement of workshops, seminars, talks, affection, exhibitions, art fair, pocket shows, perfomances and everything our bodies and minds let us do. 


Arthur Machado - Multimedia Artist, Internet and Hack Activist.

Daniel Leite - Writer, Poet and Performer.

Filipe Almeida - Designer and Graphic Artist.

Laília Cardoso - Musician. 

Larissa Costa - Illustrator, Art Educator and Photographer.

Verena Leal - Urbanist, Painter and Producer.



  • The Festival

Through an event free and open to the society, we are going to create dialogues starting from the critic and plural thought about independent cultural production, concepts of free art, possibilities of creation, reflection, development and disclosure of artistic and cultural proposals in multiple languages. The Lêstrada Free Art Festival, will aim the development of an organic activity, where the public - through an open call - will offer possibilities of cultural and artistic interventions, seminars, talks, free perfomances, shows, etc. We want to, emphatically, touch themes as independent production, hybrid art, affection, gender and surviving.

Belém is a city where the majority of the population does not have access to art and culture activities, in addiction, there is a clear anti-culture policy by the capital authorities which choose to chase, deny and suffocate multiples cultural movements and expressions, whether they are from the street or either from the most institutionalized, through a severe cut in the fundings for art policies. We have as examples of this, art movements such as Solar das Artes, As Batucadas, A Feira Libertaria, As Batalhas de Mc’s and a lot of others unfortunate episodes such as the closing of the Bar do 8. In addiction of this, the funding cuts at the Lei Semear, the twists in Tó Teixeira and the burial of the Valmir Bispo law - promoting and funding tools available (?) in Belém. The Lêstrada Free Art Festival is the result of that scene, but with the objective to recognise in the street a space of cultural resistance, where art is a result of something that changes someone who creates, who receive and absorve, therefore, we want to develop independent options, free for all, to shake the city, to create an event that evolves to the street and to open the space of Forum Landi to the formation and exchange with the communities of the surrounding and the population in general.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Jim Ditto and I am an oil painter and actor currently living in Brooklyn. As a fine artist in one of the world's primary cultural and artistic hubs, I am one of many who can speak to the difficulty of having one's work exhibited, let alone purchased. This coming May my wife, Isis, and I will be moving back to Seattle, Washington. We both grew up in the Puget Sound and have enjoyed our experiences in New York and around the globe over the last decade. With us comes a body of artwork to join the pieces I have created over the last several years back home, ready for exhibition and purchase.

I am unsatisfied with merely championing my own work and have reached out to several up and coming artists in the Seattle area. These are people I grew up with and who have finally been able to step out of art as a hobby to careers as artists. They are supporters of arts, culture, and community as I am. As such, we want to be part of the effort to keep money flowing within our community through dynamic and creative projects. SEXPUG (Seattle Exposure Pop Up Gallery) is an attempt to do just that.

What We Need & What You Get

By meeting our $10,000 minimum goal, we aim to achieve the following:

  • Rent a suitable retail space for a period of 2 months, with insurance. Areas of interest are currently Pioneer Square and Greenwood, due to their wonderful art walks.
  • Provide a weekly rotation of exhibitions, while allowing for continued display of remaining artworks
  • Hire catering, with light appetizers & cash bar
  • Produce backer rewards for our generous supporters
  • Offset the cost of transportation of Jim's work from New York
  • Pay for transportation of works to the gallery
  • Host a final event, Jim's 300 KOI Cancer Fundraiser. 300 4"x4" handpainted KOI oil paintings will be auctioned off to benefit cancer research, along with other art and items.
  • Give all profits from sales directly to the artists themselves, no fees or commissions to the gallery.

In return for your generous donations, we are able to offer a growing list of rewards:

  • Original art work!
  • 300 KOI Posters (numbered & signed)!
  • Framed prints!
  • Canvas prints!
  • Postcards!
  • Stickers!
  • Painting lessons!
If we do not reach our goal, the money will be used to produce the backer rewards, with the remainder being divided among the artists to cover other exhibition and grant application fees for the coming year. 9% of funds raised will go to Indiegogo.com and yes, we will have to pay taxes.

If we beat our goal, we will be even better prepared for additional expenses associated with the exhibition and rental. Only 4% of funds raised will go to Indiegogo.com. The further we step beyond $10,000, the larger the space and the more creative we can be. The more successful this project is, the more likely we will be able to do it again the following year. New art, new location. Hopefully paying less in taxes :^)

The Impact

With your help, SEXPUG will bring local artists together for the first time, exposing them to new audiences, and encouraging them to continue to produce. Taking the burden of rent and other associated exhibition costs from us, you are freeing us to be more creative and less demanding in our pricing. Affordable art is hard to come by because of all the costs associated with its display. We thank you in advance for choosing our project and for making the choice to crowdfund with us. It is the most democratic option in a world where money buys everything.

Can this work?

Absolutely. Pop up galleries are proving to be a successful way of providing artists and business owners alike to turn empty spaces into objects and areas of wonder, bringing aesthetic and commercial interests for the benefit of the community at hand. Our aim to be seen in areas already popular for their art walks and exhibitions should greatly improve the odds of success.

Crowdfunding works, too, as my successful KOI School campaign of 2013 can attest. With the support of my social network, I was able to raise over $3000 to purchase the supplies (canvases, paints, etc) for 12 new works, ready to be seen at my SEXPUG exhibition opening. The funds raised also covered the cost of backer rewards, some of which are being repurposed to reward backers of SEXPUG. If you didn't get the chance to get your very own 300 KOI poster, now is your chance!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to support us right now, don't worry. You can back the project now and the money will come out of your account when the campaign ends in May.

Won't have money then, either? Want to give something in addition to $$? We need you to be our champion! We need voices to share what we're doing and to draw new fans in to support this campaign. Use the buttons on this page to share on Facebook, Twitter, and everywhere else! Tell your friends, your family, your coworkers too! If they love art, if they love Seattle, if they love making a big difference with a small step, send them HERE!


A final word:

If you've read this far, thank you. Thank you so very much. Please don't let this time be a waste. Share the page, pick your backer reward, and donate. 

Then just wait to be amazed.

Merci!

Pop up galleries are proving to be a successful way of providing artists and business owners alike to turn empty spaces into objects and areas of wonder, bringing aesthetic and commercial interests for the benefit of the community at hand. Our aim to be seen in areas already popular for their art walks and exhibitions should greatly improve the odds of success.Crowdfunding works, too, as my successful KOI School campaign of 2013 can attest. With the support of my social network, I was able to raise over $3000 to purchase the supplies (canvases, paints, etc) for 12 new works, ready to be seen at my SEXPUG exhibition opening. The funds raised also covered the cost of backer rewards, some of which are being repurposed to reward backers of SEXPUG. If you didn't get the chance to get your very own 300 KOI poster, now is your chance!Other Ways You Can HelpIf you don't have the funds to support us right now, don't worry. You can back the project now and the money will come out of your account when the campaign ends in May.Won't have money then, either? Want to give something in addition to $$? We need you to be our champion! We need voices to share what we're doing and to draw new fans in to support this campaign. Use the buttons on this page to share on Facebook, Twitter, and everywhere else! Tell your friends, your family, your coworkers too! If they love art, if they love Seattle, if they love making a big difference with a small step, send them HERE!A final word:If you've read this far, thank you. Thank you so very much. Please don't let this time be a waste. Share the page, pick your backer reward, and donate. Then just wait to be amazed.Merci!

story:
What images will define our memory of an unpolluted world? Of wilderness? Are we willing yet to acknowledge that images may one day be all that’s left of an unspoiled land? And what of the soiled nature, our Pacific ocean sheathed in gyres of swirling plastic? Only sixty years after the first successful ascent of Mount Everest, humans successfully redressed the world’s tallest peak as the world's tallest trash and corpse heap. Everyday, more and more contaminants turn up in tests of river waters. From acetaminophen and caffeine, to components of birth control pills and detergents in the slimy film covering rocks, the exponential growth of chemicals intertwining themselves into the molecular structure of the natural world attests to the contemporary human love for chemical consumption. What sorrows are we willing to endure in the name of momentary comfort and convenience? How comfortable is a world with no trees? With no fresh water?

How much longer will the great tradition of the American road trip be great, let alone feasible? Point of Interest is a growing collection of visual and written essays by kindred artists and friends Lauren Kristin and Paul Thiesing, which wrestle with these questions on humans, nature and human nature. Point of Interest is about what holds our interest, why we're interested, and how we invest in our interests. Point of Interest is a book in the making of thoughtful cross-examinations dealing with the ways in which we exist in this world as humans, and the ways in which the American experience of nature is both sublime and problematic. 

What We Need 

We began this body of work in the summer of 2014 during a two month road trip of the kind American photographers and writers have likened to that of a pilgrimage. Last year’s vehicle, a 2001 Ford Focus, was notorious for overheating and after being rear-ended at a red light in Oregon, it only made it home on a miracle and with the help of some junkyard tires and a generous supply of duct tape. We were able to purchase a car for this second installment trip with just enough savings from our full-time day jobs. In order to cut down on costs during the trip, and to exist intimately in the landscape, we sleep in tents and cook on a camp stove–so this is the minimal amount of money we need to buy art supplies, gas and provisions throughout the summer.


The Perks (What You Get)
After spending the past year making sense of the work we've made, we have a clear vision and sense of direction for the project. At the present moment, our portfolios exist as a series of 24x36" prints, 11x14" silver gelatin prints, 9x16- 11x17" gouache, watercolor and china marker paintings, sketchbooks filled with studies, notebooks filled with poems and prose. We are more than willing to give these pieces of our sojourn to you in gratitude for your contribution. 

Examples of the work we are giving away can be found via here and here.

Special thank you to Gender Studies for letting us use their music.

story:
11 Days of Music, Dance, Poetry, Art, Theater...

The Infringement Festival is a grassroots, volunteer-driven arts festival in Buffalo, NY. The 2015 edition is the 12th incarnation of the festival and is set to run from July 23 - August 2.

Infringement is entirely donation-driven; the festival does not charge application fees and programs 100% of the projects that are proposed. We need funding to support certain costs to promoting the festival.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funding for publication of the schedule in The Public. 
  • Funding for back line and other equipment rental.
  • Higher funding levels will enable you to receive exclusive perks, like hand-silkscreened t-shirts and custom artwork from BIF artists.
  • All perks will be delivered by the first day of the festival. 

The Impact

Your donation supports a group of over 300 acts, from music to dance to poetry to theater and beyond. The Infringement Festival could not be produced for 12 consecutive years without funding support from you.

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks with prepaying for certain services, but we enjoy good relationships with vendors and our volunteers are on top of things. We will be in great shape 

Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer, promote, participate, and attend! If you have time to help us out, please email us at bifvolunteers@gmail.com. Share our posts on social media. Send us links to pictures and videos from the festival. Attend a fundraiser. Come to the festival! And remember, Infringe Everyday!
