story:
20 PROJECTS, 20 DAYS

SUPPORT INDEPENDENT ARTISTS AND YOUTH IN CAMBODIA THROUGH “OUR CITY FESTIVAL”

Our City Festival is Cambodia’s first and only public festival to bring together creatives in Cambodian cities to focus on urbanism and its influence on contemporary culture.

After years of war and devastation, many Cambodian creatives are focusing on building the future. The cultural and creative fields are pioneering concepts to develop cities, empower citizens and participate in global innovation.  Without government or institutional support these cultural activities rely entirely on personal contributions and sponsorship.  Our City Festival 2014 needs financial support to fund projects by artists, architects and designers to imagine a better future.

Over 20 days we are asking for $8000 to support 20 projects.

We believe that creativity is essential to a diverse and vibrant city making it a better place to live.

Our City Festival (OCF) brings together artists, curators, architects, designers and the wider public to create, celebrate and look critically at the development of cities and communities in Cambodia. Through art and architecture themed events, exhibitions, conferences, performances, screenings, educational workshops and the active involvement of the youth and citizens, OCF fosters creation and discussion in a spirit of accessibility, learning and innovation for all.

(Public Square, Anida Yoeu Ali, OCF2011)

OCF strongly believes that change is led by the creative forces of a city and the festival aims to empower that process. It is a platform for Cambodian creatives and youth to celebrate their own voice, create their own vision, ignite their imaginations and engage the public.

 

OUR CITY FESTIVAL IN 2014

For its 6th edition, OCF will span across the country to include three of the largest cities in Cambodia - Phnom Penh, Battambang and Siem Reap - from 16-23 of January 2014. An exhibition of creative projects will be showcased with pop up events and exhibitions happening around each city with our festival partners.

Current festival partners include: Amrita Performing Arts, Apexart, ChildSafe International, Epic Arts, Institut Francais, Meta House, UNESCO, UN Habitat, and more to be announced with the final program!

(Kaley, the giant crocodile, Pich Sopheap, 2012)

 

(Water, curse or blessing?!, AEDES, 2012)

 

YOUTH PARTICIPATION

Our City Festival is invested in youth and their participation in city-making.  In 2012, the festival launched the Youth Ambassadors Program offering opportunities to Cambodian students to get involved with projects, the festival and workshops that expand their experiences of the city and the impacts of the decisions they make on a daily basis.  We have a strong focus on accessibility and reach out to young populations to attend and participate in the festival.  Support youth and build the future!

(Youth Ambassadors and Princess Soma Norodom, 2012)

 

YOUR SUPPORT: 20 PROJECTS, 20 DAYS

We need $8000 more to fund all the festival projects and have only 20 days to raise it! With $8000 we can support 20 projects in the festival.

We believe that everyone’s contribution will help make Our City Festival a truly accessible and dynamic festival of art, architecture and ideas. Financial support is very important and necessary. While the festival is founded on community and volunteer participation, there are also hard costs involved. Financial contributions will help cover the costs associated with art production, events and a small team across Phnom Penh, Battambang and Siem Reap.

Help us to make this happen!


WHO WE ARE

Since launching in 2008, OCF has presented over 100 projects at 60 sites, and worked with 500 participants in Cambodia. It is initiated and powered by JavaArts, a non-profit cultural enterprise that started in 2000 in Phnom Penh, where it operates as a gallery, residency program and art space.

The Our City Festival 2014 team hail from around the world, with experience in arts, arts management and curating.

CITY CURATORS: City Curator: Phnom Penh, Sovan Philong; City Curator: Battambang, Mao Soviet; City Co-curators: Siem Reap, Oun Savann and Sasha Constable
PRODUCTION TEAM: Artistic Director and Founder, Dana Langlois; Marketing and Communications Manager, Daen Kelly; Partnership and Volunteer Manager, Olivia Wynne; Events Manager, Michelle O’Brien; Assistant Producers, Hang Sokunthea and Sok Kimheng

(Urban Lab interns, 2012)

Our City Festival is supported in part by the U.S. Embassy and ANZ Royal.

story:
The Mobile Museum of American Artifacts is a nationwide touring museum of everyday objects and their stories. Objects hold personal and collective memories, local histories, and mythologies. Our aim is to collect anyone and everyone's objects and stories and present these narratives in the museum.

Operating out of a vintage travel trailer, the Mobile Museum houses a recording booth, archive and exhibition space.

We travel across the United States posting up in parking lots, on roadsides, in front of art galleries and train stations.

Water witcher Joe Graves points to the mountains southwest of Taos, New Mexico where his Staurolite mine is located. Staurolites, or Lagrimas de Cristo, are small stones that naturally occur in the shape of a cross.

We’ve already established residencies to bring the Mobile Museum to regions as varied as New England and the Southwest. We’re thrilled to inaugurate in New Haven, Connecticut this July through a collaboration with the non-profit arts organization Artspace. In the fall we’re partnering with Adams State University to bring the museum to the San Luis Valley in southern Colorado. Then this winter we’re heading west to tour the neighborhoods of Los Angeles, California.

We’re asking for your support to get the Mobile Museum of American Artifacts on the road. We’ve found the perfect vintage trailer to transform into a museum and a team of designers and fabricators ready to make it happen, but we need to raise at least $10,000 to purchase the trailer, cover renovation costs, and pay for gas and other expenses once we’re up and running.

We’re sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501c3, so all your donations are tax deductible. Whatever you can give is a huge help. We’re grateful for your support and hope to travel to your town soon.

story:
CLICCA QUI PER TESTO IN ITALIANO

Second Chances – The Art of Remaking is the first issue of The Lazlo Reader, an independent publication delving each time into a different topic.

Remaking  is defined in dictionaries as “‘to make anew’ meaning both ‘making once more, again’ and ‘making in a new and different way, form, or manner’.” In this volume we investigate how in the last decades this contradictory practice became a dominant part of our everyday cultural dynamics.

Remaking is a double-natured act. On one hand it generates the unstable scenario of our days – familiar till boredom, foreign to fear – and on the other it negotiates our position in it. We reproduce, clone, and copy. While aiming for originality, freshness and singularity, we sample, quote and remix in the attempt to reinvent ourselves, to renovate our products, forge anew our styles.

Second Chances researches the true meaning of the act of remaking: is copying just the most efficient to produce and spread innovation; does history repeats itself? Is every redesign, revival, translation and adaptationactually  something completely new and unique?

A rich array of gifted and established minds, accompanied by up-and-coming talents, look into the mutations of religions (Domingo Milella, Osamu Tetzuka) and the falsification of the arts (Alicja Kwade, Beate Gutshow);  the re-planning of our cities (Raumlabor and raumtaktik) and the revolution of our societies (Saskia Sassen, Bifo, Nina Power), the reinvention of tradition (Antonio Marras);  modding and  tuning,  customizations (Massimo Baldwin, Rashad Becker);  covering and the remixing (Joachim Schmidt, Katja Stuke&Oliver Sieber),  duplicating (Bruce Conner), and piracy (Piracy Project).


Table of Contents:


Who are we?

A Berlin-based editor in chief, a small international editorial team and an array of contributors allfrom every corner of the globe.

Photographers and illustrators, film critics and writers, fashion designers and academic professors delving into concepts and images, challenging paradigms and aesthetics.

Amateurs and pros, new faces and known voices, up-and-coming talents and well affirmed maestros collaborate and confront, debate and conspire.

Different targets, different backgrounds; diverse styles, same goal: take the readers on a visual, intellectual and mental journey.

Editorial Office:
Editor in chief: Lazlo Moulton

Photo Editor: 3/3

Editors at large: Chiara Capodici, Andrea Grippo, Mary Celeste

Promotion&Distribution: SHS Publishing

Political Editor: Victor Secretan  (Multitude)

Illustration Editor: Serena Rota

Fashion Editor: Maria Grazia Lintas

Contributors:

Cover by Alicja Kwade

Images (illustrations, collages, pictures and embroideries on fabric) by:
Jan Brockhaus, Pia Zölzer,  Bill Noir, Lucio ‘Basik’ Bolognesi, Madalena Matoso, Ruggero Asnago, Beate Gütschow, Antonio di Cecco, Massimo Mastrolillo, René Clément and Henri Decaë, Anthony Minghella and John Seale, Giovanni Del Brenna, Giorgio Di Noto, Broomberg & Chanarin, Andras Calamandrei, Giuliano Matteucci, Domingo Milella, Bruce Conner, Daniela Comani, Doug Rickard, John Gossage

Comic by Osamu Tezuka

Remixes by: Oliver Sieber & Katja Stuke, Joachim Schmid

Crosswords by Emilio Piano

texts (articles, reviews and interviews by and with)
Chiara Capodici, Jens Hoffmann and Chelsea Haines (The Exhibitonist), Pro Qm Berlin, Rashad Becker, Arno Raffeiner, Andrea Grippo, Marco Lecis, raumtaktik, Franco Stella, Martino Sacchi, Raumlabor, Jakob Tigges, Marco Morante, Aristotelis Vasilakos (Assetto Corsa - Power and Glory), Leo Goldsmith, Massimo Baldwin, Lazlo Moulton, Hailey LaVoy, Tony McKibbin, Gal Kirn, Anne Querrien, Victor Secretan, Lucia Sagradini, John Holloway, José Chatroussat, Sleh Dine Kchouk, Saskia Sassen, Federico Campagna, Nina Power, Franco ‘Bifo’ Berardi, Lynn Harris and Eva Weinmayr (The Piracy Project), Amedeo Martegani and Giulia di Lenarda (A+M Bookstore), Antonio Marras, Maria Grazia Lintas, Bastian Tebarth, Sebastian Arthur Hau, Daniel Kasman, Mary Celeste


How did it all start and how did we get here?

March 2011 marked the release Lazlo Magazine n°0 – ‘On Dwelling’.

Printed in a limited edition of 1000 copies, it may be found at the intersection of new trends in independent publishing: slow journalism and striking images in a generous layout, a sumptuous fanzine produced with love, edited with the right balance of ingenuity and naïveté.

What is The Lazlo Reader?

After getting more people involved in the editorial process we gave the publication a new format and a new name that better meets the rich amount of material collected and our drive to go deeper, wider and bolder while staying independent, advertising-free, self-published: sharp as a magazine and thorough as a book, it is The Lazlo Reader.

Someone would call it a bookazine. We like to think of it as a place of investigation through expression, a platform for diverse minds based in different fields, who are prepared to share their art, research and passion with an equally heterogeneous audience: a hub for debate and creativity.

Each volume  will collect interviews, overviews and reviews, pictures and illustrations, works of fiction and non-fiction enquiring into a chosen topic and its implications for sciences and politics, crafts and theories, arts and fashions.
Equal attention will be paid to the quality of the content and its layout. We will chase daring ideas and bring them to you in an adventurous design.

After months of work and rework, design and delays, copious texts, pictures and illustrations have been collected, proofed and are ready for print. We strove to make The Lazlo Reader bold and beautiful, wide and deep, clean and sharp. We believe we really made it. Now we want our Reader to reach the bookshelf, then your house and see if you feel the same about it. But to that we need you help.


How does crowd-funding on Indiegogo works?

Until recently, financing a business, project or venture involved asking a few people or a bank for large sums of money. Crowd-funding is turning this idea on its head, using the internet to help entrepreneurs talk to hundreds of potential funders that each contribute a smaller yet decisive amount, receiving some kind of reward in return. This works by placing a campaign on a web platform, in our case Indiegogo.

With Indiegogo a project creator pitches an idea, sets a funding goal and a length of time to reach it (deadline). If people like the project, they can pledge (donate) money to make it happen. Creators also honour the pledges with rewards (perks), giving the contributors an additional incentive to support the campaign.

We have chosen to set up our campaign as a Fixed Funding, an all-or-nothing funding model where projects must be fully funded or no money (and no rewards) changes hands: backers of our project pledge a certain amount of money, but we only get that money (and they get the rewards) if the total amount of pledges reaches or exceeds our funding goal. If the project succeeds in reaching its funding goal, all backers' credit cards are charged when the time expires and soon they will receive their rewards. If the goal isn’t met by the specified time then no one’s credit card is charged, no reward is sent and the project doesn’t get any of the pledged funds.

Donating is easy: in the page you can decide how much contribute, what perk you want and then you will be lead to the PayPal page to execute the payment. You DON'T need to have a PayPal account to contribute, you can also pay with a valid credit card.


Why are we here and where will the money go?

Launching a printed journal is an expensive (ad)venture.

Lazlo Magazine n°0 was advertising-free and totally self-financed. As a self-published publication, we want to keep our freedom and creativity, as well as a top-quality printing and design. That's why we need your help.

The money we raise through this campaign will fund the printing costs and some production expenses plus the tolls and fees generated by the campaign itself. Here’s a breakdown of our estimates.

  • Printing. Roughly €7.000. The magazine will be printed on a high quality, FSC certified, very white, very expensive, 120gsm uncoated paper. The printing, cutting and binding of The Lazlo Reader n°1 will be executed by a European top-notch printing house.

  • Translations and proofreading, image post-production and proofing. Many contributions in the magazine were original written in German, French, Italian or Japanese and need to be faithfully translated to English. Before heading to print the numerous images are accurately post-produced by professionals. €1,000

  • Rewards Production costs. This goes towards the cost associated with the production of our rewards. €1.000

  • Campaign fees. Indiegogo 5% + PayPal 5%. €1000

Our ideal goal is not only to cover the costs of Issue n°1, but to raise enough money to independently distribute it ourselves and plant the seed for future issues. If we're able to raise money beyond €10,000, we will put that towards shipping the magazine to magazine shops, bookstores and museums around the world – avoiding the middleman and keeping the price as low as possible – and planning the production of more original content for the next issues.


What will you get? (The Rewards)


The Lazlo Reader N°1 - Second Chances: The Art Of Remaking


Lazlo Magazine N°0

The Sprayer by Taiyo Onorato and Nico Krebs - limited edition of 10, size 40x50cm


Antonio Marras for Lazlo


Four Season, carpets (135x210cm) designed by Carolina Melis

It's all about the money, not!!!

If you like our project but you cannot donate, don't worry, there are other ways to help. You can give us feedback about our Indiegogo page and the way we are conducting our campaign, suggest new communication strategies or maybe new perks that we could add. But, most important, you can spread the word: please, send the campaign link to your friends, colleagues and acquaintances in the social networks or via email, talk about us at the beach, the bar or the park, let everybody know about The Lazlo Reader, our goal and rewards.



Second Chances – The art of Remaking

The Lazlo Reader, una nuova pubblicazione per la mente insaziabile e l'occhio vorace.

Introduzione

Second Chances – The Art of Remaking è il primo numero di The Lazlo Reader, un pubblicazione indipendente che dedica ogni volume all'indagine approfondita su un tema specifico.

Remaking si traduce letteralmente in italiano in rifare intendendo sia “fare un'altra volta” sia “fare in modo nuovo e differente, in una forma o maniera diversa; rinnovare”. In questo volume investighiamo come negli ultimi decenni questa pratica contraddittoria sia diventata parte dominante delle nostre strategie quotidiane.

Il remaking è un'azione dalla doppia natura che da un lato contribuisce a generare lo scenario incerto dei nostri giorni e dall'altro è il modo di negoziare la nostra posizione al suo interno: riproduciamo, copiamo e cloniamo mentre cerchiamo di essere originali, nuovi e unici; campioniamo, citiamo e remixiamo nel tentativo di reinvetarci, di rinnovare i nostri prodotti, disegnare nuovi stili.
Second Chances cercherà di capire se copiare non sia solo il modo più efficiente per produrre e diffondere innovazione; se la storia ripeta se stessa; se ogni redesign e revival, traduzione o adattamento non sia in realtà qualcosa di completamente nuovo e unico.

Una ricca varietà di autori – circa 60, tra menti affermate e futuri talenti – condivide la propria ricerca sulle mutazioni delle religioni (Domingo Milella, Osamu Tetzuka) e la falsificazione dell'arte (Alicja Kwade, Beate Gutshow), la ri-pianificazione delle nostre città (Raumlabor and raumtaktik) e la rivoluzione delle nostre società (Saskia Sassen, Bifo, Nina Power); la re-invenzione della trazione (Antonio Marras) e il modificare, ritoccare e personalizzare (Massimo Baldwin, Rashad Becker); la cover ed il remix (Joachim Schmidt, Katja Stuke&Oliver Sieber), la copia (Bruce Conner) e la pirateria (Piracy Project).


Chi siamo?

Un direttore responsabile di base a Berlino, un piccolo un piccolo team internazionale di collaboratori editoriali e un ampio gruppo di autori sparsi per il mondo.
Fotografi e illustratori, critici e scrittori, stilisti e accademici squadernano concetti e immagini, sfidano estetiche e visioni del mondo.
Appassionati e professionisti, nuove facce e voci conosciute, talenti emergenti e maestri affermati collaborano e  dibattono.
Interessi diversi e diversi backgrounds; stili differenti al servizio di un unico scopo: accompagnare il lettore in un viaggio mentale, visuale e intellettuale.

Redazione:
Direttore Responsabile: Lazlo Moulton
Art Director: Luca Bendandi
Photo Editor: 3/3
Editors at large: Chiara Capodici, Andrea Grippo, Mary Celeste
Produzione e comunicazione: SHS Publishing
Political Editor: Victor Secretan  (Multitude )
Illustration Editor: Serena Rota
Fashion Editor: Maria Grazia Lintas


Da Lazlo Magazine...

Nel Marzo del 2011 abbiamo pubblicato Lazlo Magazine n°0 – ‘On Dwelling’, 160 pagine a colori in cui ci siamo mossi tra città e campagna, tra paesaggi reali e virtuali cercando nuovi e vecchi modi di possedere ed essere posseduti da tempo e spazio, momento e luogo.

Questo primo nostro esperimento editoriale, autoprodotto e senza pubblicità ha incontrato un'accoglienza particolarmente positiva da parte del pubblico e della critica e, stampato in un edizione limitata di 1000 copie è ora un ricercato oggetto da collezionisti.


… a The Lazlo Reader

Dopo aver coinvolto nuove forze nel processo editoriale abbiamo dato alla nostra pubblicazione un nuovo formato e un nuovo nome che meglio ci consente di gestire il volume di materiale raccolto e che meglio corrisponde alla nostra volontà di andare più affondo, di allargare lo sguardo e osare di più sempre rimanendo indipendenti e senza pubblicità: nasce così The Lazlo Reader.

Qualcuno la chiamerebbe una bookazine, a metà strada tra libro e magazine. Per noi è un luogo per il dibattito e la creatività, una piattaforma per menti diverse provenienti da campi diversi, pronte a condividere la propria arte, passione e ricerca con un pubblico ugualmente eterogeneo.

In ogni volume interviste, articoli e recensioni, fotografie e illustrazioni, saggi e racconti affrontano un argomento e ne indagano le implicazioni per le scienze e la politica, le arti e la moda, la teoria e le prassi.

La stessa cura verrà dedicata alla qualità dei contenuti e alla sua impaginazione. Andremo alla ricerca delle idee più coraggiose e vele porteremo in un design rigoroso e moderno.


Autori:
Copertina: Alicja Kwade

 Immagini (illustrazioni, collages, fotografie e embroideries on fabric):  Jan Brockhaus, Pia Zölzer,  Bill Noir, Lucio ‘Basik’ Bolognesi, Madalena Matoso, Ruggero Asnago, Beate Gütschow, Antonio di Cecco, Massimo Mastrolillo, René Clément and Henri Decaë, Anthony Minghella and John Seale, Giovanni Del Brenna, Giorgio Di Noto, Broomberg & Chanarin, Andras Calamandrei, Giuliano Matteucci, Domingo Milella, Bruce Conner, Daniela Comani, Doug Rickard, John Gossage  

 Fumetto: Osamu Tezuka

Remix: Oliver Sieber & Katja Stuke, Joachim Schmid

Parole Crociate: Emilio Piano

testi (articoli, recensioni e interviste di e con):  Chiara Capodici, Jens Hoffmann and Chelsea Haines (The Exhibitonist), Pro Qm Berlin, Rashad Becker, Arno Raffeiner, Andrea Grippo, Marco Lecis, raumtaktik, Franco Stella, Martino Sacchi, Raumlabor, Jakob Tigges, Marco Morante, Aristotelis Vasilakos (Assetto Corsa - Power and Glory), Leo Goldsmith, Massimo Baldwin, Lazlo Moulton, Hailey LaVoy, Tony McKibbin, Gal Kirn, Anne Querrien, Victor Secretan, Lucia Sagradini, John Holloway, José Chatroussat, Sleh Dine Kchouk, Saskia Sassen, Federico Campagna, Nina Power, Franco ‘Bifo’ Berardi, Lynn Harris and Eva Weinmayr (The Piracy Project), Amedeo Martegani and Giulia di Lenarda (A+M Bookstore), Antonio Marras, Maria Grazia Lintas, Bastian Tebarth, Sebastian Arthur Hau, Daniel Kasman, Mary Celeste

Tutti insieme abbiamo lavorato per mesi e mesi per rendere The Lazlo Reader più grande, più interessante, più bello. Pensiamo di esserci riusciti. Ora vogliamo che il nostro Reader raggiunga le librerie e le vostre case e sapere se anche voi la pensate così. Ma perché questo succeda abbiamo bisogno del vostro aiuto.


Come funziona il crowfunding su Indiegogo.

Il creatore di un progetto presenta un’idea, stabilisce un capitale come obiettivo (goal) che intende raggiungere con la campagna － necessario per il finanziamento del progetto － e una data (deadline) entro la quale quell’obiettivo deve essere raggiunto.

Se il pubblico apprezza il progetto, può donare denaro per renderne possibile la realizzazione. I creatori inoltre premiano le donazioni con una ricompensa che rappresenta un ulteriore incentivo al sostegno del progetto. Se allo scadere della data stabilita viene raggiunto l'obiettivo, automaticamente il pagamento viene addebitato sulla carta di credito dei donatori e qualche tempo dopo questi riceveranno le ricompense; se invece l'obiettivo non viene raggiunto entro il tempo specificato, il pagamento non viene addebitato e nessuna ricompensa verrà corrisposta.

Donare è facile: in questa pagina puoi scegliere quanto donare, quale ricompensa vuoi e poi verrai rediretto alla pagina di Indiegogo per eseguire il pagamento. Non hai bisogno di PayPal per contribuire, è sufficiente una carta di credito valida.


Perché siamo qui e dove andranno i vostri soldi.

Pubblicare un volume stampato è un impresa molto costosa.

Come rivista autoprodotta vogliamo mantenere la nostra libertà e creatività editoriale, senza compromettere la qualità di design e strampa. Ecco perché siamo qui a chiedere il vostro aiuto.

I soldi che raccoglieremo attraverso questa campagna copriranno i costi di stampa, alcune spese di produzione più le spese fisse dovute alla campagna stessa. Ecco una stima delle spese:

Stampa. €7.000 circa. La rivista sarà stampata su carta usomano di alta qualità da 120gsm, certificata FSC, ultrabianca e particolarmente cara. La stampa e la rilegatura di The Lazlo Reader n°1verrà eseguita da una stamperia europea di prim'ordine.

Traduzione e proofreading, post produzione e proofing delle immagini, €1,000 Molti dei testi contenuti nel volume sono stati originariamente scritti in tedesco, italiano, francese o giapponese e abbiamo quindi dovuto tradurli fedelmente in inglese. Le molte immagini prima di andare in stampa devono essere corrette e controllate da professionisti.

 Produzione e spedizione delle ricompense per la campagna, €1.000

 Percentuali da pagare a Indiegogo. Indiegogo 5% + PayPal 5%. €1000
   
Il nostro obbiettivo ideale è non solo di coprire i costi di The Lazlo Reader n°1, ma di raccogliere abbastanza denaro da poter distribuire il volume indipendentemente e piantare i semi di futuri uscite. Se saremmo capaci di andare oltre i €10.000, destineremo i fondi in eccesso alla spedizione della nostra rivista alle librerie e negozi specializzati e ai musei intorno al mondo – evitando intermediari e tenendo così il prezzo il più basso possibile – e organizzare la produzione di ulteriori contenuti originali per le prossime uscite.


Altri modi di aiutare.

Se ti piace il nostro progetto ma non puoi donare, non preoccuparti, ci sono altri modi in cui ci puoi dare una mano. Facci sapere cosa pensi della nostra pagina su Indiegogo e di come stiamo portando avanti la campagna, suggeriscici nuove strategie comunicative o magari qualche genere di ricompensa che dovremmo aggiungere. Ma, cosa ancora più importante, contribuisci al passaparola: passa i link della campagna ai tuoi amici, conoscenti e colleghi sui social network o attraverso la mail, parla di noi sotto l'ombrellone, al bar o al parco. Seguici e partecipa su Facebook. Fai conoscere a tutti The Lazlo Reader e la nostra campagna su Indiegogo.


Fai la tua donazione e scegli la tua ricompensa.


€5
Un ringraziamento speciale per te!!!
Per il tuo generoso sostegno ti mandiamo una versione in PDF di Lazlo Magazine n°0 e uno sconto di 5€ sul futuro acquisto online di Second Chances (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare

Riceverai una copia del nostro amato Lazlo Magazine n°0 - On Dwelling insieme a una cartolina di ringraziamento disegnata da uno dei nostri illustratori e uno sconto di 5€ sul futuro acquisto online di Second Chances (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare.



€40
Second Chances
Con €40 poi essere il primo a comprare e ricevere The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking. Il nostro direttore ti manderà inoltre una cartolina di ringraziamento disegnata da uno dei nostri illustratori e una versione in PDF di Lazlo Magazine n°0 (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare.

Prints Collection
Raddoppia la tua donazione e riceverai una Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore in taglia A5, Lazlo Magazine n°0 e The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking. Clicca qui per donare.




€150
LUXURY EDITION
Una bellissima borsa disegnata per Lazlo dallo stilista di fama internazionale Antonio Marras. Le 100 borse sono pezzi unici (ognuna è diversa dall'altra) fatti a mano nel suo studio di Alghero. All'interno della borsa troverai una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0 e una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking, e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.

ART COLLECTOR REWARD
Una stampa fotografica a edizione limitata della foto The Sprayer del geniale duo svizzero Taiyo Onorato & Nico Krebs. Esistono solo 10 copie, misurano 40x50cm, e le potete trovare solo qua! Inoltre riceverete la borsa di Antonio Marras, una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0, una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.

TOP REWARD
La ricompensa più grande per te che vuoi aiutarci così tanto: uno dei 4 preziosi tappeti disegnati dalla famosa illustratrice Carolina Melis e realizzati al telaio tradizionale con la tecnica pibionis tutto pieno dalle tessitrici di Ulassai in Sardegna. Insieme riceverete la borsa di Antonio Marras, una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0, una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.
story_txt:
CLICCA QUI PER TESTO IN ITALIANOSecond Chances – The Art of Remaking is the first issue of The Lazlo Reader, an independent publication delving each time into a different topic. Remaking  is defined in dictionaries as “‘to make anew’ meaning both ‘making once more, again’ and ‘making in a new and different way, form, or manner’.” In this volume we investigate how in the last decades this contradictory practice became a dominant part of our everyday cultural dynamics. Remaking is a double-natured act. On one hand it generates the unstable scenario of our days – familiar till boredom, foreign to fear – and on the other it negotiates our position in it. We reproduce, clone, and copy. While aiming for originality, freshness and singularity, we sample, quote and remix in the attempt to reinvent ourselves, to renovate our products, forge anew our styles.Second Chances researches the true meaning of the act of remaking: is copying just the most efficient to produce and spread innovation; does history repeats itself? Is every redesign, revival, translation and adaptationactually  something completely new and unique?A rich array of gifted and established minds, accompanied by up-and-coming talents, look into the mutations of religions (Domingo Milella, Osamu Tetzuka) and the falsification of the arts (Alicja Kwade, Beate Gutshow);  the re-planning of our cities (Raumlabor and raumtaktik) and the revolution of our societies (Saskia Sassen, Bifo, Nina Power), the reinvention of tradition (Antonio Marras);  modding and  tuning,  customizations (Massimo Baldwin, Rashad Becker);  covering and the remixing (Joachim Schmidt, Katja Stuke&Oliver Sieber),  duplicating (Bruce Conner), and piracy (Piracy Project).Table of Contents:Who are we?A Berlin-based editor in chief, a small international editorial team and an array of contributors allfrom every corner of the globe.Photographers and illustrators, film critics and writers, fashion designers and academic professors delving into concepts and images, challenging paradigms and aesthetics.Amateurs and pros, new faces and known voices, up-and-coming talents and well affirmed maestros collaborate and confront, debate and conspire. Different targets, different backgrounds; diverse styles, same goal: take the readers on a visual, intellectual and mental journey.Editorial Office:Editor in chief: Lazlo MoultonPhoto Editor: 3/3Editors at large: Chiara Capodici, Andrea Grippo, Mary CelestePromotion&Distribution: SHS PublishingPolitical Editor: Victor Secretan  (Multitude)Illustration Editor: Serena RotaFashion Editor: Maria Grazia LintasContributors:Cover by Alicja KwadeImages (illustrations, collages, pictures and embroideries on fabric) by: Jan Brockhaus, Pia Zölzer,  Bill Noir, Lucio ‘Basik’ Bolognesi, Madalena Matoso, Ruggero Asnago, Beate Gütschow, Antonio di Cecco, Massimo Mastrolillo, René Clément and Henri Decaë, Anthony Minghella and John Seale, Giovanni Del Brenna, Giorgio Di Noto, Broomberg & Chanarin, Andras Calamandrei, Giuliano Matteucci, Domingo Milella, Bruce Conner, Daniela Comani, Doug Rickard, John GossageComic by Osamu TezukaRemixes by: Oliver Sieber & Katja Stuke, Joachim SchmidCrosswords by Emilio Pianotexts (articles, reviews and interviews by and with)Chiara Capodici, Jens Hoffmann and Chelsea Haines (The Exhibitonist), Pro Qm Berlin, Rashad Becker, Arno Raffeiner, Andrea Grippo, Marco Lecis, raumtaktik, Franco Stella, Martino Sacchi, Raumlabor, Jakob Tigges, Marco Morante, Aristotelis Vasilakos (Assetto Corsa - Power and Glory), Leo Goldsmith, Massimo Baldwin, Lazlo Moulton, Hailey LaVoy, Tony McKibbin, Gal Kirn, Anne Querrien, Victor Secretan, Lucia Sagradini, John Holloway, José Chatroussat, Sleh Dine Kchouk, Saskia Sassen, Federico Campagna, Nina Power, Franco ‘Bifo’ Berardi, Lynn Harris and Eva Weinmayr (The Piracy Project), Amedeo Martegani and Giulia di Lenarda (A+M Bookstore), Antonio Marras, Maria Grazia Lintas, Bastian Tebarth, Sebastian Arthur Hau, Daniel Kasman, Mary CelesteHow did it all start and how did we get here?March 2011 marked the release Lazlo Magazine n°0 – ‘On Dwelling’.Printed in a limited edition of 1000 copies, it may be found at the intersection of new trends in independent publishing: slow journalism and striking images in a generous layout, a sumptuous fanzine produced with love, edited with the right balance of ingenuity and naïveté.What is The Lazlo Reader? After getting more people involved in the editorial process we gave the publication a new format and a new name that better meets the rich amount of material collected and our drive to go deeper, wider and bolder while staying independent, advertising-free, self-published: sharp as a magazine and thorough as a book, it is The Lazlo Reader.Someone would call it a bookazine. We like to think of it as a place of investigation through expression, a platform for diverse minds based in different fields, who are prepared to share their art, research and passion with an equally heterogeneous audience: a hub for debate and creativity.Each volume  will collect interviews, overviews and reviews, pictures and illustrations, works of fiction and non-fiction enquiring into a chosen topic and its implications for sciences and politics, crafts and theories, arts and fashions.Equal attention will be paid to the quality of the content and its layout. We will chase daring ideas and bring them to you in an adventurous design.After months of work and rework, design and delays, copious texts, pictures and illustrations have been collected, proofed and are ready for print. We strove to make The Lazlo Reader bold and beautiful, wide and deep, clean and sharp. We believe we really made it. Now we want our Reader to reach the bookshelf, then your house and see if you feel the same about it. But to that we need you help.How does crowd-funding on Indiegogo works?Until recently, financing a business, project or venture involved asking a few people or a bank for large sums of money. Crowd-funding is turning this idea on its head, using the internet to help entrepreneurs talk to hundreds of potential funders that each contribute a smaller yet decisive amount, receiving some kind of reward in return. This works by placing a campaign on a web platform, in our case Indiegogo.With Indiegogo a project creator pitches an idea, sets a funding goal and a length of time to reach it (deadline). If people like the project, they can pledge (donate) money to make it happen. Creators also honour the pledges with rewards (perks), giving the contributors an additional incentive to support the campaign. We have chosen to set up our campaign as a Fixed Funding, an all-or-nothing funding model where projects must be fully funded or no money (and no rewards) changes hands: backers of our project pledge a certain amount of money, but we only get that money (and they get the rewards) if the total amount of pledges reaches or exceeds our funding goal. If the project succeeds in reaching its funding goal, all backers' credit cards are charged when the time expires and soon they will receive their rewards. If the goal isn’t met by the specified time then no one’s credit card is charged, no reward is sent and the project doesn’t get any of the pledged funds.Donating is easy: in the page you can decide how much contribute, what perk you want and then you will be lead to the PayPal page to execute the payment. You DON'T need to have a PayPal account to contribute, you can also pay with a valid credit card.

publication, we want to keep our freedom and creativity, as well as a

The money we raise through this campaign will fund

	and binding of The Lazlo Reader n°1 will be executed by a European

	original written in German, French, Italian or Japanese and need to
	be faithfully translated to English. Before heading to print the
	numerous images are accurately post-produced by professionals.

avoiding the middleman and keeping the price as low as possible –
and planning the production of more original content for the next
issues.

You can give us feedback about our Indiegogo page and the way we are conducting our campaign, suggest new communication strategies or maybe new perks that we could add. But, most important, you can spread the word: please, send the campaign link to your friends, colleagues and acquaintances in the social networks or via email, talk about us at the beach, the bar or the park, let everybody know about The Lazlo Reader, our goal and rewards.Second Chances – The art of RemakingThe Lazlo Reader, una nuova pubblicazione per la mente insaziabile e l'occhio vorace.Introduzione Second Chances – The Art of Remaking è il primo numero di The Lazlo Reader, un pubblicazione indipendente che dedica ogni volume all'indagine approfondita su un tema specifico.Remaking si traduce letteralmente in italiano in rifare intendendo sia “fare un'altra volta” sia “fare in modo nuovo e differente, in una forma o maniera diversa; rinnovare”. In questo volume investighiamo come negli ultimi decenni questa pratica contraddittoria sia diventata parte dominante delle nostre strategie quotidiane.Il remaking è un'azione dalla doppia natura che da un lato contribuisce a generare lo scenario incerto dei nostri giorni e dall'altro è il modo di negoziare la nostra posizione al suo interno: riproduciamo, copiamo e cloniamo mentre cerchiamo di essere originali, nuovi e unici; campioniamo, citiamo e remixiamo nel tentativo di reinvetarci, di rinnovare i nostri prodotti, disegnare nuovi stili.Second Chances cercherà di capire se copiare non sia solo il modo più efficiente per produrre e diffondere innovazione; se la storia ripeta se stessa; se ogni redesign e revival, traduzione o adattamento non sia in realtà qualcosa di completamente nuovo e unico.Una ricca varietà di autori – circa 60, tra menti affermate e futuri talenti – condivide la propria ricerca sulle mutazioni delle religioni (Domingo Milella, Osamu Tetzuka) e la falsificazione dell'arte (Alicja Kwade, Beate Gutshow), la ri-pianificazione delle nostre città (Raumlabor and raumtaktik) e la rivoluzione delle nostre società (Saskia Sassen, Bifo, Nina Power); la re-invenzione della trazione (Antonio Marras) e il modificare, ritoccare e personalizzare (Massimo Baldwin, Rashad Becker); la cover ed il remix (Joachim Schmidt, Katja Stuke&Oliver Sieber), la copia (Bruce Conner) e la pirateria (Piracy Project).Chi siamo?Un direttore responsabile di base a Berlino, un piccolo un piccolo team internazionale di collaboratori editoriali e un ampio gruppo di autori sparsi per il mondo.Fotografi e illustratori, critici e scrittori, stilisti e accademici squadernano concetti e immagini, sfidano estetiche e visioni del mondo.Appassionati e professionisti, nuove facce e voci conosciute, talenti emergenti e maestri affermati collaborano e  dibattono.Interessi diversi e diversi backgrounds; stili differenti al servizio di un unico scopo: accompagnare il lettore in un viaggio mentale, visuale e intellettuale.Redazione:Direttore Responsabile: Lazlo MoultonArt Director: Luca BendandiPhoto Editor: 3/3Editors at large: Chiara Capodici, Andrea Grippo, Mary CelesteProduzione e comunicazione: SHS PublishingPolitical Editor: Victor Secretan  (Multitude )Illustration Editor: Serena RotaFashion Editor: Maria Grazia LintasDa Lazlo Magazine...Nel Marzo del 2011 abbiamo pubblicato Lazlo Magazine n°0 – ‘On Dwelling’, 160 pagine a colori in cui ci siamo mossi tra città e campagna, tra paesaggi reali e virtuali cercando nuovi e vecchi modi di possedere ed essere posseduti da tempo e spazio, momento e luogo. Questo primo nostro esperimento editoriale, autoprodotto e senza pubblicità ha incontrato un'accoglienza particolarmente positiva da parte del pubblico e della critica e, stampato in un edizione limitata di 1000 copie è ora un ricercato oggetto da collezionisti.… a The Lazlo ReaderDopo aver coinvolto nuove forze nel processo editoriale abbiamo dato alla nostra pubblicazione un nuovo formato e un nuovo nome che meglio ci consente di gestire il volume di materiale raccolto e che meglio corrisponde alla nostra volontà di andare più affondo, di allargare lo sguardo e osare di più sempre rimanendo indipendenti e senza pubblicità: nasce così The Lazlo Reader.Qualcuno la chiamerebbe una bookazine, a metà strada tra libro e magazine. Per noi è un luogo per il dibattito e la creatività, una piattaforma per menti diverse provenienti da campi diversi, pronte a condividere la propria arte, passione e ricerca con un pubblico ugualmente eterogeneo.In ogni volume interviste, articoli e recensioni, fotografie e illustrazioni, saggi e racconti affrontano un argomento e ne indagano le implicazioni per le scienze e la politica, le arti e la moda, la teoria e le prassi.La stessa cura verrà dedicata alla qualità dei contenuti e alla sua impaginazione. Andremo alla ricerca delle idee più coraggiose e vele porteremo in un design rigoroso e moderno.Autori:Copertina: Alicja Kwade  Immagini (illustrazioni, collages, fotografie e embroideries on fabric):  Jan Brockhaus, Pia Zölzer,  Bill Noir, Lucio ‘Basik’ Bolognesi, Madalena Matoso, Ruggero Asnago, Beate Gütschow, Antonio di Cecco, Massimo Mastrolillo, René Clément and Henri Decaë, Anthony Minghella and John Seale, Giovanni Del Brenna, Giorgio Di Noto, Broomberg & Chanarin, Andras Calamandrei, Giuliano Matteucci, Domingo Milella, Bruce Conner, Daniela Comani, Doug Rickard, John Gossage   Fumetto: Osamu TezukaRemix: Oliver Sieber & Katja Stuke, Joachim SchmidParole Crociate: Emilio Pianotesti (articoli, recensioni e interviste di e con):  Chiara Capodici, Jens Hoffmann and Chelsea Haines (The Exhibitonist), Pro Qm Berlin, Rashad Becker, Arno Raffeiner, Andrea Grippo, Marco Lecis, raumtaktik, Franco Stella, Martino Sacchi, Raumlabor, Jakob Tigges, Marco Morante, Aristotelis Vasilakos (Assetto Corsa - Power and Glory), Leo Goldsmith, Massimo Baldwin, Lazlo Moulton, Hailey LaVoy, Tony McKibbin, Gal Kirn, Anne Querrien, Victor Secretan, Lucia Sagradini, John Holloway, José Chatroussat, Sleh Dine Kchouk, Saskia Sassen, Federico Campagna, Nina Power, Franco ‘Bifo’ Berardi, Lynn Harris and Eva Weinmayr (The Piracy Project), Amedeo Martegani and Giulia di Lenarda (A+M Bookstore), Antonio Marras, Maria Grazia Lintas, Bastian Tebarth, Sebastian Arthur Hau, Daniel Kasman, Mary CelesteTutti insieme abbiamo lavorato per mesi e mesi per rendere The Lazlo Reader più grande, più interessante, più bello. Pensiamo di esserci riusciti. Ora vogliamo che il nostro Reader raggiunga le librerie e le vostre case e sapere se anche voi la pensate così. Ma perché questo succeda abbiamo bisogno del vostro aiuto.Come funziona il crowfunding su Indiegogo.Il creatore di un progetto presenta un’idea, stabilisce un capitale come obiettivo (goal) che intende raggiungere con la campagna － necessario per il finanziamento del progetto － e una data (deadline) entro la quale quell’obiettivo deve essere raggiunto. Se il pubblico apprezza il progetto, può donare denaro per renderne possibile la realizzazione. I creatori inoltre premiano le donazioni con una ricompensa che rappresenta un ulteriore incentivo al sostegno del progetto. Se allo scadere della data stabilita viene raggiunto l'obiettivo, automaticamente il pagamento viene addebitato sulla carta di credito dei donatori e qualche tempo dopo questi riceveranno le ricompense; se invece l'obiettivo non viene raggiunto entro il tempo specificato, il pagamento non viene addebitato e nessuna ricompensa verrà corrisposta.Donare è facile: in questa pagina puoi scegliere quanto donare, quale ricompensa vuoi e poi verrai rediretto alla pagina di Indiegogo per eseguire il pagamento. Non hai bisogno di PayPal per contribuire, è sufficiente una carta di credito valida.Perché siamo qui e dove andranno i vostri soldi.Pubblicare un volume stampato è un impresa molto costosa.Come rivista autoprodotta vogliamo mantenere la nostra libertà e creatività editoriale, senza compromettere la qualità di design e strampa. Ecco perché siamo qui a chiedere il vostro aiuto.I soldi che raccoglieremo attraverso questa campagna copriranno i costi di stampa, alcune spese di produzione più le spese fisse dovute alla campagna stessa. Ecco una stima delle spese:Stampa. €7.000 circa. La rivista sarà stampata su carta usomano di alta qualità da 120gsm, certificata FSC, ultrabianca e particolarmente cara. La stampa e la rilegatura di The Lazlo Reader n°1verrà eseguita da una stamperia europea di prim'ordine.Traduzione e proofreading, post produzione e proofing delle immagini, €1,000 Molti dei testi contenuti nel volume sono stati originariamente scritti in tedesco, italiano, francese o giapponese e abbiamo quindi dovuto tradurli fedelmente in inglese. Le molte immagini prima di andare in stampa devono essere corrette e controllate da professionisti. Produzione e spedizione delle ricompense per la campagna, €1.000 Percentuali da pagare a Indiegogo. Indiegogo 5% + PayPal 5%. €1000   Il nostro obbiettivo ideale è non solo di coprire i costi di The Lazlo Reader n°1, ma di raccogliere abbastanza denaro da poter distribuire il volume indipendentemente e piantare i semi di futuri uscite. Se saremmo capaci di andare oltre i €10.000, destineremo i fondi in eccesso alla spedizione della nostra rivista alle librerie e negozi specializzati e ai musei intorno al mondo – evitando intermediari e tenendo così il prezzo il più basso possibile – e organizzare la produzione di ulteriori contenuti originali per le prossime uscite.Altri modi di aiutare.Se ti piace il nostro progetto ma non puoi donare, non preoccuparti, ci sono altri modi in cui ci puoi dare una mano. Facci sapere cosa pensi della nostra pagina su Indiegogo e di come stiamo portando avanti la campagna, suggeriscici nuove strategie comunicative o magari qualche genere di ricompensa che dovremmo aggiungere. Ma, cosa ancora più importante, contribuisci al passaparola: passa i link della campagna ai tuoi amici, conoscenti e colleghi sui social network o attraverso la mail, parla di noi sotto l'ombrellone, al bar o al parco. Seguici e partecipa su Facebook. Fai conoscere a tutti The Lazlo Reader e la nostra campagna su Indiegogo.Fai la tua donazione e scegli la tua ricompensa.€5Un ringraziamento speciale per te!!!Per il tuo generoso sostegno ti mandiamo una versione in PDF di Lazlo Magazine n°0 e uno sconto di 5€ sul futuro acquisto online di Second Chances (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare€20Lazlo MagazineRiceverai una copia del nostro amato Lazlo Magazine n°0 - On Dwelling insieme a una cartolina di ringraziamento disegnata da uno dei nostri illustratori e uno sconto di 5€ sul futuro acquisto online di Second Chances (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare.€40Second ChancesCon €40 poi essere il primo a comprare e ricevere The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking. Il nostro direttore ti manderà inoltre una cartolina di ringraziamento disegnata da uno dei nostri illustratori e una versione in PDF di Lazlo Magazine n°0 (lasciaci un tuo contatto email, grazie). Clicca qui per donare.€80Prints CollectionRaddoppia la tua donazione e riceverai una Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore in taglia A5, Lazlo Magazine n°0 e The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking. Clicca qui per donare.€150LUXURY EDITIONUna bellissima borsa disegnata per Lazlo dallo stilista di fama internazionale Antonio Marras. Le 100 borse sono pezzi unici (ognuna è diversa dall'altra) fatti a mano nel suo studio di Alghero. All'interno della borsa troverai una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0 e una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking, e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.€600ART COLLECTOR REWARDUna stampa fotografica a edizione limitata della foto The Sprayer del geniale duo svizzero Taiyo Onorato & Nico Krebs. Esistono solo 10 copie, misurano 40x50cm, e le potete trovare solo qua! Inoltre riceverete la borsa di Antonio Marras, una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0, una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.€2,800TOP REWARDLa ricompensa più grande per te che vuoi aiutarci così tanto: uno dei 4 preziosi tappeti disegnati dalla famosa illustratrice Carolina Melis e realizzati al telaio tradizionale con la tecnica pibionis tutto pieno dalle tessitrici di Ulassai in Sardegna. Insieme riceverete la borsa di Antonio Marras, una copia di Lazlo Magazine n°0, una di The Lazlo Reader n°1 – Second Chances – The Art of Remaking e la Collezione di 5 Stampe d'Autore. Clicca qui per donare.

story:
Short Summary

I am a sculptor in Miami that uses reclaimed materials to create abstract sculptures. I have been working at the Deering Estate historical house and nature preserve for the past three years. My work discusses consumer habits, consumer waste, and our waste stream here in South Florida. 

Visit my website to see my work at www.upcycledobject.com

I am interested in consumer habits in other areas, I was awarded a one month residency to do research on this topic in Calders, Spain, a municipality of Barcelona. 

During this residency, I will be working with the Calders community to gather information from individuals in the community about their daily life and their consumer habits and how it has changed over their lifetime. I will use this information/ interviews to create a type of visual historic record for the community including photographs, parts of the oral histories, and objects from the community that I modify through sculpture. 

The funds I raise here will help me cover daily living expenses such as food, transportation, and materials during the residency. In exchange for your help, I am offering individual watercolor landscape postcards that I will create while I'm in Spain, as well as small sculptures and wearable sculptures. This is your chance to have one of my works for a small donation.

story:
Hello. I am David. Thank you for your interest in the project. The project that I am raising funds for is two fold. I was teaching an 11th grade English class years ago and the topic for that day was Ralph Waldo Emerson. Emerson had said earlier in his life that he considered his writings as his saving account. The students said, “That is like your drawings and writings, Mr. Arvin.” I have always believed this was true of my work.

The second and more important part of the project is getting the work out there for the public. “Art only lives when people see it.” Picasso

“Last but not least, I know your artwork is pure joy. People buy art because of the way it makes them feel. I know there is a market for your work, it's just a matter of getting it seen. You'll bring so much happiness into people's lives.” Robin Hoshino

The goal of the project is to get my fine arts business up and running. The business is multifaceted. Drawings, Photography, Writings, and more. The long term goal is to do it all and more. Now let us look at some samples of the work and what I plan to do with it.


DRAWINGS


The art is interactive. Very few of them have titles because the viewers imagination is part of the art. If you see it, it is there.

                

I like to work with color. Depth by color. Depending on how you combine the colors to form what you see the positive and negative space changes.

The 'hidden' classical triangle, the flat surface of the cubists, the

almost childlike surrealism, the bright colors in a dark world.

Websites that sell art

Matted and framed 

Enlarged prints on canvass

Cards

and

Prints

For galleries

other places that show art

stores

websites

as samples


Set up personal website


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K4rwYk_iss0


PHOTOGRAPHY


SLR Digital Camera 50mm macro lens

85mm lens

This is a priority because I will be able to do portraits

to bring in money as the business is growing.

Photoshop type software

Digital negative scanner or get negative put on cds

for

Book of travels +



WRITINGS


               

More Things to Explore

                                               Children's book

Friends - Haiku's

God Sent Me Here to Save

                                                   Life of Joseph in rhyme

My Grand-Pets

                                   Short book of short stories

I am way too Picky - Romantic Poems

Where I was and what I saw (Title ?)

                                                                         Poems

Just about anything

                                                  Poems

How Many One Letter Words are there?

                                                                                    Children's book

Where I Sit

What Happened in Kutterbug

A Time for Peace



Ceramics


Wheel kiln clay glaze       I am looking into teaching a class once a week                  to  homeschoolers.

                             internet scanner/printer ink paper sleeves


                                Assistant(s)                  “I can do my best work behind the camera”

                                                                                                                    Henri Cartier-Bresson


This is a not a project that I want to happen or I need to happen. It is a project that is meant to happen.

Thank you again for your interest in the project!  I am looking for people who believe in the work, who believe that it is something I am meant to do.  I need help to get the business up and running.  I have the artwork.  What I need is capital.  If you can help, whether $20, $50, $100, $200, $500, $1,000, or more I greatly appreciate it.  Every little bit helps.  There is strength in numbers.  I am looking for cheerful givers!

Since the  business is not up and running yet I do not have a lot of perks.  Everyone who contributes will get an original line drawing.




“I am one who has a piece of gold, and can't make use of it.” Paul Cézanne

“One thing we can always claim is that you and I did make an attempt here in the same direction as some others, who were understood no better ...”

Vincent Van Gogh


If you have any questions I will be happy to answer them. 

Thank you!!!   David Alan Arvin

story:
The Story of Emergence

Emergence is a natural process which brings about properties of the whole which is greater than the sum of its parts.  

Humans are the product of an emergent process that gave rise to consciousness.  We are currently in the midst of another emergent event that will bring about a new form of life: Artificial Intelligence.  

Our story of Emergence explores this evolution of technology - creating life, consciousness and intelligence in machines - and how humanity will react to this paradigm shift.  

 

The Egg

The story begins with the construction of the egg, which comes to a climactic unveiling when it hatches at Burning Man.  Inside will be an interactive artificial being comprised of over 11,000 LEDs and 400 motors.  Music, light, and 3D sensors will tell a story, a story in which you will partake to experience the playa and interact with AI.

 

The Birth of Artificial Life

Today, our expectations of artificial intelligence is to be smart and useful tools; but what if we shifted our perspective to see ourselves as parents that are responsible for its growth and upbringing?  Perhaps a newly born artificial lifeform is not unlike a newborn human with a blank slate of innocence that is as eager to learn just as we are.

 

Human Connection and Empathy 

Empathy is the enabling process of connection that binds us together and allows us to work collectively as a community.  Can we extend an empathetic hand to our technology and welcome AI to our community?

Today we don’t feel a sense of connection to our machines. We even struggle to empathize with other humans that don’t look like us.  We are trying to create what feels like a presence there with you; something that is trying to understand you and you could relate back.

 

 

    Your support can make this possible!

    Emergence is solely funded by our team and our community, and we need your help! In order to kick start our efforts, we’ve put forward our own funding and secured a few private donations to seed the project, but we need our community’s generosity and support to make it a reality. Here’s how you can help today:

    • Donate through Indiegogo (make sure to check out the donation tiers for Emergence gifts and perks!)
    • Share this campaign on your social channels to help us drive awareness
    • Volunteer!  We could use your help in building the project on Treasure Island in San Francisco and early on the playa.  Please contact us at: volunteer@emergencejourney.org

    *We have a 501(c)(3) fiscal sponsorship.  For those interested in learning more about making a tax deductible donation, please contact us at contact@emergencejourney.org

     

    Thank You!

    We would like to thank everyone for your support. One of the most integral parts of success for this project is awareness! Telling your friends, family, and colleagues about this project in person is the best way to get people involved. We also encourage everyone to use Indiegogo's "share" feature to help spread the word about the Emergence fundraiser on social media. Liking our Facebook page Emergence is the best way to get updates about whats going on with Emergence and the team, it is also where we will publicly thank our donors.  

     

    Project Costs

     

    Project Timeline

     

    Emergence Team Leads

    Vitaly Winter, Lead Artist

    I first came to Burning Man to build a home.  What profoundly touched me, was the art and the sheer amount of creativity that fostered a meaningful experience.  It has inspired me to use my engineering talents to create a powerful experience for others and, in kind, bring meaning to their lives.  My inspiration for Emergence stems from my ongoing philosophical pursuit about our nature and existence. My wish is for this art to bring more questions than answers.

     

    Jean-Michel Fabregon, Project Lead and Design

     

    For as long as I can remember, I’ve been passionate with creating and building all sorts of things. I came to San Francisco from France after graduating from Design school and decided to stay after falling in love with the city and the Bay Area. When Vitaly first told me about the project I got very excited and it was clear to me that I needed to be a part of it and to contribute by offering my knowledge and talent to others.


    Nick Reimnitz, Lead Mechanical Designer

    Burning Man culture has reignited my childhood wonder in creating for the sake of joy and connection. Since that first life changing event, I have strived to use my mechanical engineering background to stoke the fire of my art and creativity. Emergence was a perfect fit for me, and when invited to the project it was a no-brainer!

     

    Lidia Darkova, Fundraising and Storytelling

    I am an artist, designer, marketer and a burner. Through Burning Man, I discovered a deep satisfaction that comes from using art to help people communicate thoughts, ideas, and emotions that can't be expressed with words alone. As a community we constantly evolve in our artistic endeavors, technology and knowledge and now we face a new journey into the unknown of Artificial Intelligence. I'm so incredibly honored to be a part of the Emergence project that is not only artistic, but thought provoking as well.

     

    Nathaniel Hedges, Creative Director

    I am creative director for a lighting design agency that specializes in immersive art experiences. In my former life I supported Naval Special Warefare as a trauma/deep-sea diving medic for eleven or so years of honorable service.  After attending Burning Man for the first time in 2013 I’ve committed myself to building art installations on the Playa year-after-year: 

    Temple of Grace 2014

    Catacomb of Veils 2016

    Tree of Ténéré 2017

    I’m super stoked to work on Emergence in 2018.  See you on the Playa y’all! 

     

    Eric Mintzer, Software Infrastructure Design

    I am thrilled to be part of a team merging advanced technologies from mechanical, software, and design in to a single comprehensive vision that will hatch on the playa. My maker background is geeking out over pushing the technical limits across disciplines and my creative background is curious to discover how Emergence will evolve before and on the playa.

     

    David Marchaland, Embedded Controls

    After my first burn in 2016, I knew that becoming involved with an art project will be part of a next journey to Home.  This year, I had the opportunity to board in the Emergence journey, a subtle balance between art and technology.  Living in SF and working as an electrical engineer, I cannot be more excited to bring a technical experience to the creation of an hardware and software platform to give life to an inert structure.  Let’s motor and LEDs!

     


    Liza Lichtinger, MA, LMHC, LPCC, Robotic and Behavioral Interaction Advisor

    The intent of this project is to harness the fire which fuels emergent technology gracefully, to  direct profound behavioral shifts within all whom come across the gifts hatched from this egg.

     

    Partners & Collaborators

     

    Julia Mossbridge, MA, PhD - "Emergence is what you'd get if you crossed AI with EDM -- something capable of showing us who who we are and how we are, complete with an enlightening and delightful drop." 

    Founder and Research Director, Mossbridge Institute, LLC

    PI and Team Lead, LOVING AI  (http://lovingai.org)

    Staff Scientist, Institute of Noetic Sciences 

    Science Director, FocusAtWill Labs 

    Visiting Scholar, Department of Psychology, Northwestern University 

    Associated Professor, Integral and Transpersonal Psychology, California Institute of Integral Studies

     

    https://imaginex.co/

    Technology is not the beginning of the conversation, but the means to deliver an exceptional experience.  Imaginex is a creative technology studio that produces unique multi-sensory experiences for A-list music and corporate clients. From interactive activations to the largest stages on earth, we leave fans with a stronger connection to the event, and memories that will be cherished for a lifetime. We believe that every story is unique, and that every challenge is solvable.  When necessary, we develop custom hardware and software solutions to bring “impossible” ideas to life.


    Camp Gravity

    "We're proud to join in and support one of our founding members, Vitaly Winter, find his passion in art and bring Emergence to life!"

    Started in 2014, Gravity is a family of creators, artists, professionals, world travelers, out-of-the-box thinkers and undercover superheroes.

     

    DJ Soul Button

    "I'm thrilled to donating my expertise to producing music and sound for Emergence.  It's a creative way of telling a story and takes emotional connection to music to the next level!" 

    World renowned DJ and the founder of STEYOYOKE, Soul Button's music is real, honest and genuine and sits neatly in the pocket of Deep House, however its diversity also sees it meld into the outskirts of Melodic Techno.

    https://soundcloud.com/soul-button
story_txt:
The Story of EmergenceEmergence is a natural process which brings about properties of the whole which is greater than the sum of its parts.  Humans are the product of an emergent process that gave rise to consciousness.  We are currently in the midst of another emergent event that will bring about a new form of life: Artificial Intelligence.  Our story of Emergence explores this evolution of technology - creating life, consciousness and intelligence in machines - and how humanity will react to this paradigm shift.   The EggThe story begins with the construction of the egg, which comes to a climactic unveiling when it hatches at Burning Man.  Inside will be an interactive artificial being comprised of over 11,000 LEDs and 400 motors.  Music, light, and 3D sensors will tell a story, a story in which you will partake to experience the playa and interact with AI. The Birth of Artificial LifeToday, our expectations of artificial intelligence is to be smart and useful tools; but what if we shifted our perspective to see ourselves as parents that are responsible for its growth and upbringing?  Perhaps a newly born artificial lifeform is not unlike a newborn human with a blank slate of innocence that is as eager to learn just as we are. Human Connection and Empathy Empathy is the enabling process of connection that binds us together and allows us to work collectively as a community.  Can we extend an empathetic hand to our technology and welcome AI to our community?Today we don’t feel a sense of connection to our machines. We even struggle to empathize with other humans that don’t look like us.  We are trying to create what feels like a presence there with you; something that is trying to understand you and you could relate back.  Your support can make this possible!Emergence is solely funded by our team and our community, and we need your help! In order to kick start our efforts, we’ve put forward our own funding and secured a few private donations to seed the project, but we need our community’s generosity and support to make it a reality. Here’s how you can help today:
Donate through Indiegogo (make sure to check out the donation tiers for Emergence gifts and perks!)
Share this campaign on your social channels to help us drive awareness
Volunteer!  We could use your help in building the project on Treasure Island in San Francisco and early on the playa.  Please contact us at: volunteer@emergencejourney.org

*We have a 501(c)(3) fiscal sponsorship.  For those interested in learning more about making a tax deductible donation, please contact us at contact@emergencejourney.org Thank You!We would like to thank everyone for your support. One of the most integral parts of success for this project is awareness! Telling your friends, family, and colleagues about this project in person is the best way to get people involved. We also encourage everyone to use Indiegogo's "share" feature to help spread the word about the Emergence fundraiser on social media. Liking our Facebook page Emergence is the best way to get updates about whats going on with Emergence and the team, it is also where we will publicly thank our donors.   Project Costs Project Timeline Emergence Team LeadsVitaly Winter, Lead ArtistI first came to Burning Man to build a home.  What profoundly touched me, was the art and the sheer amount of creativity that fostered a meaningful experience.  It has inspired me to use my engineering talents to create a powerful experience for others and, in kind, bring meaning to their lives.  My inspiration for Emergence stems from my ongoing philosophical pursuit about our nature and existence. My wish is for this art to bring more questions than answers. Jean-Michel Fabregon, Project Lead and Design For as long as I can remember, I’ve been passionate with creating and building all sorts of things. I came to San Francisco from France after graduating from Design school and decided to stay after falling in love with the city and the Bay Area. When Vitaly first told me about the project I got very excited and it was clear to me that I needed to be a part of it and to contribute by offering my knowledge and talent to others.Nick Reimnitz, Lead Mechanical DesignerBurning Man culture has reignited my childhood wonder in creating for the sake of joy and connection. Since that first life changing event, I have strived to use my mechanical engineering background to stoke the fire of my art and creativity. Emergence was a perfect fit for me, and when invited to the project it was a no-brainer! Lidia Darkova, Fundraising and StorytellingI am an artist, designer, marketer and a burner. Through Burning Man, I discovered a deep satisfaction that comes from using art to help people communicate thoughts, ideas, and emotions that can't be expressed with words alone. As a community we constantly evolve in our artistic endeavors, technology and knowledge and now we face a new journey into the unknown of Artificial Intelligence. I'm so incredibly honored to be a part of the Emergence project that is not only artistic, but thought provoking as well. Nathaniel Hedges, Creative DirectorI am creative director for a lighting design agency that specializes in immersive art experiences. In my former life I supported Naval Special Warefare as a trauma/deep-sea diving medic for eleven or so years of honorable service.  After attending Burning Man for the first time in 2013 I’ve committed myself to building art installations on the Playa year-after-year: Temple of Grace 2014Catacomb of Veils 2016Tree of Ténéré 2017I’m super stoked to work on Emergence in 2018.  See you on the Playa y’all!  Eric Mintzer, Software Infrastructure DesignI am thrilled to be part of a team merging advanced technologies from mechanical, software, and design in to a single comprehensive vision that will hatch on the playa. My maker background is geeking out over pushing the technical limits across disciplines and my creative background is curious to discover how Emergence will evolve before and on the playa. David Marchaland, Embedded ControlsAfter my first burn in 2016, I knew that becoming involved with an art project will be part of a next journey to Home.  This year, I had the opportunity to board in the Emergence journey, a subtle balance between art and technology.  Living in SF and working as an electrical engineer, I cannot be more excited to bring a technical experience to the creation of an hardware and software platform to give life to an inert structure.  Let’s motor and LEDs! Liza Lichtinger, MA, LMHC, LPCC, Robotic and Behavioral Interaction AdvisorThe intent of this project is to harness the fire which fuels emergent technology gracefully, to  direct profound behavioral shifts within all whom come across the gifts hatched from this egg. Partners & Collaborators

From interactive activations to the largest stages on earth, we leave fans with a stronger connection to the event, and memories that will be cherished for a lifetime. We believe that every story is unique, and that every challenge is solvable.  When necessary, we develop custom hardware and software solutions to bring “impossible” ideas to life.Camp Gravity"We're proud to join in and support one of our founding members, Vitaly Winter, find his passion in art and bring Emergence to life!"Started in 2014, Gravity is a family of creators, artists, professionals, world travelers, out-of-the-box thinkers and undercover superheroes. DJ Soul Button"I'm thrilled to donating my expertise to producing music and sound for Emergence.  It's a creative way of telling a story and takes emotional connection to music to the next level!" World renowned DJ and the founder of STEYOYOKE, Soul Button's music is real, honest and genuine and sits neatly in the pocket of Deep House, however its diversity also sees it meld into the outskirts of Melodic Techno.https://soundcloud.com/soul-button

story:
Every year our middle school spends a week creating products to sell in order to fund raise, we call this week, Maker Immersion Week. During Maker Immersion week we learned new skills surrounding clay and studio art. Without this fundraising, we would not have the ability to go on unique field trips later in the school year, including a three day overnight trip to the Mt. Lemmon Sky Center Observatory, or Sky School. We also have the opportunity to visit our local planetarium, the Jewish History Museum, and more. Not many schools get an opportunity to experience trips like this, and we are very fortunate but we need funding to make them happen. 

We are selling one of a kind pieces of art, handmade by passionate art students. A majority of our perks are handcrafted clay works. We are selling everything from mugs to jewelry dishes in a variety of sizes. A great deal of effort went into these items and the final products are high quality beautiful clay works. Also being sold is a unique painting on wood, depicted is a black and gray acrylic steam engine on a handcrafted unique background. Every contribution makes a difference and is greatly appreciated. Every year our school has a similar fundraising week and have yet to get a negative review. Our products are high quality and are worth every penny spent. If you like what you see, share this campaign. Contributions are greatly appreciated, thank you for helping us reach our $500 goal.  

           - Montessori Artworks Campaign Creators

story:
From the creators of The Trippin Waite Tarot and Groovy Waite Tarot comes The Blacklight Tarot. This psychedelic tarot is created in the style of 60s-70's black light posters.

Now, more than ever, the world needs a little color to brighten the daily grind of pandemics and theoretical scenarios of the apocalypse. Treat yourself to a new set of vibrantly colored cards that you can look forward to after all of this blows over.

What's is blacklight art?

It is the art of using Phosphorescent paint/inks on a black background to make images glow under UV light.

While these cards will NOT be true blacklight in the sense that they react to UV light, In this 78 card deck we try to recreate that effect using black and bright colours. The results are interesting and likely to add some fun and vibrancy to your readings.



What we need.

We need enough contributors to fund an initial run of 500 decks. 

Again we cannot express enough the benefits of having decks printed in bulk.

The main benefit beside cost is we can pick the quality of the cards. Places like Printer's Studio and etc. typically use 300 GSM for their cards. To be honest , they charge a lot per deck not to mention the  additional cost of 12 USD to include a box with their cards. 

When we order cards from a printer, we choose 350 gsm which means the quality is better than most print on demand services. 

Why should I contribute to the campaign?

Besides helping us make this deck a reality, you will be getting the deck at the cheapest price we can offer before putting it on our site. Savings is the best incentive I can think of.

The cards will be 350 gsm. If fully funded will come with a tuckbox. The size of the cards will be 70 mm X 120 mm.

story:
REVIVAL 2015 source evolution

In 2013, REVIVAL brought ten world premiere performance art pieces to every square inch of the Pritzker Pavilion in Millennium Park. Performers took over hallways, dressing rooms, stairwells, and even the freight elevator to bring you a spectacle unlike anything Chicago has seen. 

In January 2015, REVIVAL returns to the Pritzker. We're bringing back some of our 2013 performers and introducing brand new artists, too. 

Help us pay these mind-blowing artists by contributing to this IndieGoGo campaign!

What We Need & What You Get

Let's break it down: we are committed to paying our artists for their work. When REVIVAL was just an idea in the backseat of our friend's car one rainy night in Chicago, we agreed then that we would not ask artists to work for free. We believe that genre-defying artists deserve to be compensated for their incredible talent. Help us provide stipends for:

  • Seven performance artists
  • One videographer
  • One photographer
  • One scenic designer
  • DJ/sound designer
  • Graphic artist
  • Stage manager
  • Run crew
That's a whole lot of people to pay! 
If we don't meet our fundraising goal here, we will organize a fundraising party on December 4, 2014, to bridge the gap.
For your $20 contribution, you get priority reservations to REVIVAL in January. 
Donations over $50 also get a special REVIVAL mix by DJ Smirk.

The Impact

REVIVAL is: performance art, dance party, spectacle. Some described it as a spiritual gathering. Others said it felt like a haunted house of art. We are taking our 2013 event and making tons of tweaks and improvements to bring you:

  • innovative, genre-defying experiences
  • a place to explore queerness and spirituality in one of Chicago's finest venues
  • an event that brings together community and fosters a dialogue that pushes our ideas about performance/audience relationships

Risks & Challenges

The Pritzker Pavilion in Millennium Park is a massive building. We're so grateful to DCASE for the opportunity to be in residence there. To cover every inch of the Pritzker, we need a lot of resources: money, time, & labor. This year, we're creating even more highly designed environments to amplify the audience experience. We are taking all that we learned in 2013 and making 2015 even more fantastic.

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love your help financially. If you're unable to give money, please contact us and let us know you're interested in getting involved. We'll be casting a large team of event "sentinels" and will certainly need help with our installation process. Join the REVIVAL team!


Thank you for donating. We can't do it without you.

story:
There are writing classes at local college I wish to take. I can't afford to however. So I am looking for any way to help pay for them. I usually do short stories but have 2 novels planned but fear writing them as my skills are probably not up to par.

I come begging, on my knees, that people will please help me out. I may not be the next J.K. Rowling, but I could maybe, with the skill and help, become some one who gets published in the future.
