story:
Background (aka Crap You Might Want to Know Before Giving a Potential Stranger Money That They Might Just Use For Drugs or Terrorist Activities Instead of Coming Through on Their Promise)

Hi everyone! I'm Franz!


Some people know me better as the Supreme Commander of the Shadow Government (or just "Supreme") but chances are, if you're seeing this, you already know me personally and understand I don't fuck with weak shit.

..and if you don't:
#1: Nice to meet you.
#2: I've been successfully making shady-seeming experiences like this for over a decade*.
#3: We should probably be friends because we share a love of awesome stuff.

*Check out StreetWars, Rental Car Rally, 666 Burger, Flavortripping to get a sense of stuff I've done and how I'm not just trying to steal your money.

So, right...now that we have that out of the way...

The Bedouin.

I've gotten obsessed with the idea of creating a high-end mobile speakeasy that's SUPER easy to build and breakdown, can easily be adjusted to fit in various spaces and constantly changes theme/location.

Said obsession led me to research the shit out of the concept and I figured out how to make it happen - at a reasonable cost and with maximum badassness.
I'm talking proper seating, leather walls, suggestive lighting, an actual bar and a sound system...and DJ.

Check out the actual wall material we're using: 

Peep the accent lighting:

Look at this bar seating: 

All this to give you an idea of how effing classy this joint is going to be...


What I Need

All-in, I'm looking at about $1400 worth of materials that I can then re-use to make this happen multiple times. I'm not talking about liquor but, the lighting, the tables/chairs/couches, the giant mirror, the bar, and that totally sweet gold and black lizard leather interior.


What You Get

Your generous contribution will get you 2 drinks and entrance to this totally sweet Yakuza Kingpin inspired coke-den club from the mid 80s. Also, you'll be all VIP'd up so you can invite friends to this hidden secret and be all popular and in-the-know (this will help to get you laid). 

Assuming this is successful, you'll also get dibs on coming/inviting friends to other versions of this that I'm planning for LA, SF, London and Detroit. 


The Impact

NYC will suck a little less and going out for a drink will be infinitely more interesting.


Risks & Challenges

The only real risk is the cops and the fact that they might shut this down and fine/arrest me. That said, it will never be in the same location, it looks totally normal and not shady from the outside and it will never be in one place for long. So good luck, Porkchop.


I wish I could say that there are other challenges but, seriously, I got this. Also, I have other people with skillz working on this so, like it will be smooth as baby-ass in execution.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share the fuck out of this shit.

story:
I'm Mark Ari. I'm a writer, painter, and musician.

My books, particularly my novel, The Shoemaker's Tale, have received critical acclaim in both literary and trade magazines and newspapers.  My paintings have been exhibited in group and solo shows in France, Spain, and in various cities in the United States, including New York.   I've performed extensively, and I'm an award-winning teacher at the University of North Florida (I know, you'd think I'd have some dough. Ha!).  As well, I edit and produce EAT Poems, an audio chapbook series of poets reading their own work,  and I serve as editorial adviser to the literary journal, Fiction Fix. 

Come the end of December, I've an opportunity to devote myself for several months to a project that includes making a series paintings to accompany stories I intend to write. Recently, an accident caused me to lose a supply of expensive paper I'd been hording for years,  a supply I was counting on for my project.  It's a problem.  I was already concerned about how to get colors, brushes, and other supplies I need. I've not got dime one to replace that paper,

Your contributions will help put me back on track.  Otherwise, truth is I don't know how I'm going to do it.


What I Need & What I Can Offer

  • I lost 67 large sheets of 300 lb Arches watercolor paper (cold press and rough) and a 51" by 10 yard roll of 156 lb Arches cold press paper. It will cost approximates $750 to replace that.
  • I don't know much about perks. But I can offer signed copies of my most appreciated book, The Shoemaker's Tale, as well as audio chapbooks and albums.  And, for large contributors, an original painting chosen from what's available at the time.  All perks will be distributed no later than the end of the campaign.
  • If I don't reach my goal, I'll use what funds there are for paper nonetheless.  If I beat my goal, the extra money will go toward other supplies.

The Impact

  • This is where I'm supposed to tell you how valuable my project is to you and the world.  I always figured it's up to other folks to decide that.  What I can say is that I wouldn't spend my heart and soul on this if I didn't think it meant something real and important.

Risks & Challenges

Bottom line is that I don't know how the project will turn out.  There are costs involved in everything, and time gets gobbled up by all the things life throws at you.  But I do have a chunk of time.  While it may not be as much as one might dream of, it's more than many others get.  One way or another, the project will get done.  If I've got to work on scraps and with the poorest materials, I'll do that. It wouldn't be new to me.  I'm a pretty devoted guy.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you don't have the wherewithal to make a contribution, I get it. No worries.  But whether you do or don't, there are other ways to help:

    • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • And if you have paper, color, or brushes you're not using, I'd appreciate if you could send them my way.

    Contact Mark Ari:  markari@live.com
story_txt:
I'm Mark Ari. I'm a writer, painter, and musician.
My books, particularly my novel, The Shoemaker's Tale, have received critical acclaim in both literary and trade magazines and newspapers.  My paintings have been exhibited in group and solo shows in France, Spain, and in various cities in the United States, including New York.   I've performed extensively, and I'm an award-winning teacher at the University of North Florida (I know, you'd think I'd have some dough. Ha!).  As well, I edit and produce EAT Poems, an audio chapbook series of poets reading their own work,  and I serve as editorial adviser to the literary journal, Fiction Fix. 
Come the end of December, I've an opportunity to devote myself for several months to a project that includes making a series paintings to accompany stories I intend to write. Recently, an accident caused me to lose a supply of expensive paper I'd been hording for years,  a supply I was counting on for my project.  It's a problem.  I was already concerned about how to get colors, brushes, and other supplies I need. I've not got dime one to replace that paper,
Your contributions will help put me back on track.  Otherwise, truth is I don't know how I'm going to do it.
   What I Need & What I Can Offer 
I lost 67 large sheets of 300 lb Arches watercolor paper (cold press and rough) and a 51" by 10 yard roll of 156 lb Arches cold press paper. It will cost approximates $750 to replace that.
I don't know much about perks. But I can offer signed copies of my most appreciated book, The Shoemaker's Tale, as well as audio chapbooks and albums.  And, for large contributors, an original painting chosen from what's available at the time.  All perks will be distributed no later than the end of the campaign. If I don't reach my goal, I'll use what funds there are for paper nonetheless.  If I beat my goal, the extra money will go toward other supplies. 
  The Impact 
This is where I'm supposed to tell you how valuable my project is to you and the world.  I always figured it's up to other folks to decide that.  What I can say is that I wouldn't spend my heart and soul on this if I didn't think it meant something real and important. 
  Risks & Challenges Bottom line is that I don't know how the project will turn out.  There are costs involved in everything, and time gets gobbled up by all the things life throws at you.  But I do have a chunk of time.  While it may not be as much as one might dream of, it's more than many others get.  One way or another, the project will get done.  If I've got to work on scraps and with the poorest materials, I'll do that. It wouldn't be new to me.  I'm a pretty devoted guy.

  Other Ways You Can Help If you don't have the wherewithal to make a contribution, I get it. No worries.  But whether you do or don't, there are other ways to help: 
Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools!
And if you have paper, color, or brushes you're not using, I'd appreciate if you could send them my way.

 Contact Mark Ari:  markari@live.com

story:
Who?   François Michaud, visual artist from
Sète, France and creator of international project”  Hearts of the world”

Where?   At
L'école Victor-Brodeur, francophone school, part of the Francophone District #
93 of British Columbia, on Head Street, Victoria

What?  Creation
of a permanent sculpture of a heart using wood as a material from British
Columbia. This heart project, part of the worldly “Heart Project” will
give  a pulse of the world as the other
hearts already installed around the 
planet!  At the school level,  many other educational projects will be born
with the participation of teachers and students from Kindergarten to grade
twelve: such as themes of the heart like physical activities=health of the heart,
ecology=health of our planet, .collaboration, mutual aid and support of
relations  at school between the anglophone, francophone and first nations communities.This project was globally acclaimed and was featured in a documentary produced by ARTE (German TV Channel) as well as received many reviews by international medias.  For complementary information
you can view the artist web site at the following address:  www. Françoismichaud.fr 

Why?   To further and increase the standing
of artistic expression, cultural diversity, human values of the heart and put
the school in a project of international nature.How
can you contribute? By making a monetary donation or giving
services( see annex)

Why
should you contribute?  To
support your community and think globally by acting locally!

« Projet Cœurs du monde »

Qui?    François
Michaud, artiste visuel vivant à Sète en France et créateur du projet
international « Cœurs du monde ».

Où?   À l’école Victor-Brodeur, école francophone de la Commission scolaire
francophone de la Colombie-Britannique, rue Head à Victoria C.-B.

Quoi?   Entre le15 février et le 07
mars 2014, réalisation d’une sculpture permanente, un cœur en bois, qui
s’inscrivant dans le concept entier du projet qu’il a créé en 2010, deviendra
un autre « pouls du monde » tel qu’il en a déjà installé ailleurs sur
la planète.  A cette occasion, plusieurs
projets pédagogiques impliquant professeurs et élèves de la maternelle à la
douzième année verront le jour sur des thèmes du cœur : activités
physiques=santé du coeur, écologie=santé de la planète,  collaboration, entraide et soutien= santé des
relations à l’école et des communautés anglophones-francophones-autochtones. Ce projet a été reconnu internationalement
et ARTE (chaîne de télévision allemande) produit actuellement un documentaire
sur l’artiste tandis que plusieurs autres médias ont publiés à ce sujet.  Pour de plus amples informations, veuillez
consulter le site de l’artiste à l’adresse suivante : www.françoismichaud.fr 

Pourquoi?   Pour favoriser et
valoriser l’expression artistique, la diversité culturelle, les valeurs
humaines du cœur et inscrire l’école dans un projet à caractère
international.  De plus, ce cœur installé
en permanence sera un lieu de médiation symbolique permettant le règlement de
conflits entre étudiants.

Comment
pouvez-vous y contribuer?   Contribution financière ou en services (voir annexe).

Pourquoi y
contribuer?  Pour soutenir votre communauté en pensant globalement  et en agissant localement.

En retour en tant
que donateur? 

• Un reçu de charité permettant une déduction d’impôt;

• Une visibilité accrue de votre service ou produit
auprès des 500 familles francophones dans les publications de l’école et de la
Commission scolaire francophone (CSF) de toute la C.B. dès l’implication et
tout au cours du projet (site internet, publications, publi-reportage, etc.);

Lors de la soirée de dévoilement de l’œuvre 07 mars 2014  en
présence des parents, professeurs, représentants de la CSF et médias :

• Un siège réservé au premier rang;

• Un certificat officiel attestant votre soutien financier au projet;

• Remerciements sur le site de l’artiste avec diffusion internationale;

• Une superbe occasion de redonner à votre communauté;

Vous remerciant à
l’avance de votre généreuse contribution!

De : L’équipe du projet Cœurs du monde et tous les étudiants

story:
Over the years the Black Sassy Collective has curated the Weld Echo exhibitions with over 1000 artists, many thousands of people visit the forests in the city by immersing themselves in Weld Echo.

$2600 will pay the deposit for the gallery for our 9thannual art exhibition Weld Echo 2014 and pay our cutting edge designer for our new exciting campaign.

Weld Echo

Since 2005, the Black Sassy Artist Collective has curated the annual Weld echo art exhibition. A collaborative exhibition displaying works inspired by the Weld Valley of Southern Tasmania.

For the first time since the first Weld Echo exhibition, a large tract of once threatened forests of the Weld Valley have been protected as World Heritage listed.

Weld Echo 2014 is held from 8-22 January.

The Black Sassy Artists Collective is a community collective of artisans, poets, creative and musicians, inspired by the wild lands of Tasmania’s forests, rivers and sea.

The Black Sassy Collective mission is to encourage and empower, inspire and educate people about the beauty and integrity of keeping these wild lands intact. intact these wild lands.

Design is Art and Activism

Our organisation has a designer who is cutting edge at his work for the forests in digital campaigning. He has been volunteering his efforts for years. As a family man who needs to eat and design, we are raising funds for his next campaign project with our organisation.

What will we use $2600 for?

$1100 deposit for gallery hire

$500 printing and posting invitations,

$1000 paying our graphic designer for our next campaign project

Our grassroots forest advocacy organisation provides a staunch and independent voice for the forests and forest dependent species that face destruction at the hands of Tasmania’s logging industries. Spearheading a campaign in Tasmania against Ta Ann, a Malaysian logging and palm oil cartel from Sarawak, who produces veneer in Tasmania using native forests timber.

More ways you can help

Collaborate in the exhibition!

Email: huonenvironmentcentre@gmail.com and find out how you can exhibit with us.

story:
I'm Bjoern Thomas, contemporary art photographer, living partly in Germany. I would be honored if you read this or watch my 

ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART 

video. 


What is ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART?

The ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART campaign is the worldwide first art event in space - a historic project for our mankind.

You might ask yourself what is the link between art and space? Space and the dream to find a second earth in the universe always carried a tremendous fascination for people, while the desire to dive into a new world is also an important task of art.

The way we explore the galaxy is changing dramatically since the last years with huge private investments of Richard Branson, Elon Musk and other visionaries. Now it gets time for the "Space 2.0" mission of contemporary art.

I will trigger this by executing as first artist an art project in space, which should not only geographically widen the horizon of the human world. This initiative might help to self-reflect, inspires in following your "no limits, no boarders" dreams but also offers others the opportunity to take actively part (or passive as sponsor) in this unique cultural event.

The ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART initiative will be executed in 2 main steps, a major space escape project on earth called "ART SPACE" in summer 2014 and an amazing "SPACE ART" project during my suborbital trip with a real spacecraft in 2016. I started already with my astronaut training and successfully passed the G-force-test.


How to finance and execute this project?

The "ART SPACE" project phase requires an involvement of around 200 artists from all countries in the world to design their proposal for the flag for the space or universe, a public web-page for an online voting of the winning flag, a similar number of actors in the Mojave desert which represent the earth and a merry-go-around as symbol for childhood, gravity and it's analogy to the biblical Ark Noah. The unique picture will be taken also from a helicopter perspective. 

The estimated project cost for the "ART SPACE" project has been calculated with US30.000$.

The final "SPACE ART" project phase is planned for 2016, right after the development of the spacecraft from ZENOVISION. Their spacecraft will be specialized on broadcasting and camera technology, this is the main reason why I have chosen ZENOVISION for the sub-orbital flight and this art project. Just watch this for further details on the spacecraft: http://zenovision.com. 

On the flight I'll take the flag of the universe (result of the ART SPACE phase) in the sub-orbit and take pictures from the flag, space and our earth with a special camera. This unique event will be broadcasted to the earth in real-time. The project cost for this phase were calculated with $ US140.000, about $ US115.000 for the suborbital flight and training causes and $ US25.000 for the technical implementation, like broadcasting it from space.

The ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART, a historic project for our mankind, will require in total $ US 170.000. In case the IndieGoGo funding campaign will not cover the entire amount, I will apply for institutional or corporate art sponsoring programs to close the gap. Not realizing this art project is NO OPTION! 


What is your benefit for supporting this initiative?

Your funding will help me to realize the dream to connects the art world with the discovery of the universe, which is a unique source for inspiration and creativity.

I will offer very special perks for all supporters, like:

  • E-Book, ART SPACE or SPACE ART catalog from the artist
  • Participating as actor in the Mojave desert (ART SPACE)
  • Signed fine art prints from the ART SPACE or SPACE ART project
  • Publishing the sponsor names on a webpage, logo shirt or even broadcasting it live from the sub-orbit in a banner 
  • Receiving a original piece of the space flag in a frame (which was used for the SPACE ART project)


I would be glad if you talk to others about it, whether in a direct dialogue with your friends, with your "Like" on Facebook or by forwarding this link. This would be a great support also from all those who can't support the ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART project monetarily.


And who is Bjoern Thomas?

I'm a globetrotter and worked for almost 6 years in more than 20 countries on all continents.

I use photography in an experimental way or to discover foreign elements prevalent in our society, exploring sub-cultures one does not personally understand. Examples for this are my gangster pictures or images from real sumo fighters. Many of my projects are difficult to implement in other eyes, but not for me.

My work has been shown in the last year at SCOPE ART MIAMI, SHANGHAI ART FAIR, ART FAIR COLOGNE or instantaneously SAATCHI MUSEUM in London on a screen. The publication of my artistic creations lead already to far more than half a million clicks on my website or personal iTunes channel.

Besides the art photography I gained an engineering degree from an university in Germany and MBA degree from Purdue, which is famous in the space and aerospace industry. Those multiple experiences lead me partly to this dream and supports me in realizing the unique ART SPACE FOR SPACE ART project.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, and thank you in advance for your kind attention. I am trying to accomplish a few things actually.

  • To provide myself with a studio to conduct my business as a photographer.
  • To work with other groups and individuals to help them acheive rehearsal space needs.
  • To provide initial space for the creation of a small for profit Theatre Group


What We Need & What You Get


  • We need a commercial space to set up in, we would prefer to pay in full and not carry a debt.
  • Marketing, advertising, and cost of business funds for the first twelve months.
  • If the entire goal is not met, we will utilize the funds to set up other fundraising means, or if it is still substantial all will go to the down-payment and mortgage on a space.

The Impact


  • Yes, primarily this will benefit me, my wife , and our kids to further my business.
  • It will also provide opportunities in the community for other groups and individuals to better afford space.
  • I decided that I did not want there to be many layers of giving. I would prefer folks to only give one dollar each. something small, something almost anyone can afford, and an experiment that proves the theory that while no one can do it all, very few weights are too heavy when everyone lifts.

Risks & Challenges

  • It will take a great deal of work from more than a few people to realize this dream.
  • There will be an opportunity for groups and individuals that cannot help with the financial improvement of the space to offer sweat equity instead so they may still have a space to practice their gifts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • I really think this is affordable for anyone, but if not if you can just share this with everyone you know you will be counted as one of the group.
  • Please use indigogo share tools and all means of social media to help.

Thank you for your attention, and now on with the experiment.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Laura Dicus, an artist enamoured of realism, color and detail.  I like to capture a rare moment or something of beauty and share them with you through my paintings.

The Bluewater Artworks Gallery and I have just signed a contract for my work to be displayed.  This is a big step up for me both as validation for my passion and as a source of income during these difficult times.

Your willingness to support me will help spread beauty which is something I believe is extremely important.

What We Need & What You Get


  • I have framed my original paintings and high quality prints for shows: a light mat and simple frame is usually required.  I have reframed one painting for the gallery and it has cost over $600.00!  I won't be choosing frames as fancy (or costly) but the work will have to be brought up to this gallery's expectations.
  • We recently found a leak in my studio.  This puts my paintings, prints and materials at risk.  The estimate to fix this is $680.00
  • I have beautiful giclee prints of my work available for you as a reward for your support.  These prints are printed on 100% cotton art paper and the inks are guaranteed to last 125 years in normal interior conditions. (yes, they are in a protected area right now.)
  • For the artists out there I'm offering another perk: for a $25 contribution you'll receive 3 5ml tubes of Winsor & Newton artists grade watercolor tubes!  The colors available are listed in the Updates section.  Just click the Updates tab above.
  • I have chosen a flexible campaign so even if I don't reach my entire goal I will be able to provide fewer pieces of framed work and several unframed prints.  This also means you will get your perk even if the goal isn't reached.
  • If I exceed my goal I will produce greeting cards which have been requested by this gallery and several businesses here and on Maui.


The Impact


  • Your generosity will help me get more work displayed, spreading beauty and joy, encouraging other struggling artists to express themselves and it will just plain feel good.
  • I'll be able to get the leak in the studio fixed too.  That's a really important as leaking water raises humidity that can compromise everything from paper stock, mats and prints.  (Don't worry, the prints are protected.  I'd just like to get  everything put back in its place!)
  • I really believe that good things and people are out there who believe the arts are an essential part of our lives and culture.

Other Ways You Can Help


  • I've added a new incentive!  Refer 3 people who contribute and receive a free miniature giclee print of "Evanescent Peace", see the photo in the Gallery.
  • I know there are a lot of you who are in dire straights and just can't afford to hand over money yet still believe in supporting the arts.  You can!   Spread the word,not only with social media but local arts groups, friends and family.  Let's do this!
  • By the way, Indiegogo has great share tools to make this easier!

Thank you all from the bottom of my heart!
story_txt:
Short SummaryI'm Laura Dicus, an artist enamoured of realism, color and detail.  I like to capture a rare moment or something of beauty and share them with you through my paintings.The Bluewater Artworks Gallery and I have just signed a contract for my work to be displayed.  This is a big step up for me both as validation for my passion and as a source of income during these difficult times.Your willingness to support me will help spread beauty which is something I believe is extremely important.What We Need & What You Get
I have framed my original paintings and high quality prints for shows: a light mat and simple frame is usually required.  I have reframed one painting for the gallery and it has cost over $600.00!  I won't be choosing frames as fancy (or costly) but the work will have to be brought up to this gallery's expectations.
We recently found a leak in my studio.  This puts my paintings, prints and materials at risk.  The estimate to fix this is $680.00
I have beautiful giclee prints of my work available for you as a reward for your support.  These prints are printed on 100% cotton art paper and the inks are guaranteed to last 125 years in normal interior conditions. (yes, they are in a protected area right now.)
For the artists out there I'm offering another perk: for a $25 contribution you'll receive 3 5ml tubes of Winsor & Newton artists grade watercolor tubes!  The colors available are listed in the Updates section.  Just click the Updates tab above.
I have chosen a flexible campaign so even if I don't reach my entire goal I will be able to provide fewer pieces of framed work and several unframed prints.  This also means you will get your perk even if the goal isn't reached.
If I exceed my goal I will produce greeting cards which have been requested by this gallery and several businesses here and on Maui.
The Impact
Your generosity will help me get more work displayed, spreading beauty and joy, encouraging other struggling artists to express themselves and it will just plain feel good.
I'll be able to get the leak in the studio fixed too.  That's a really important as leaking water raises humidity that can compromise everything from paper stock, mats and prints.  (Don't worry, the prints are protected.  I'd just like to get  everything put back in its place!)
I really believe that good things and people are out there who believe the arts are an essential part of our lives and culture.
Other Ways You Can Help
I've added a new incentive!  Refer 3 people who contribute and receive a free miniature giclee print of "Evanescent Peace", see the photo in the Gallery.
I know there are a lot of you who are in dire straights and just can't afford to hand over money yet still believe in supporting the arts.  You can!   Spread the word,not only with social media but local arts groups, friends and family.  Let's do this!
By the way, Indiegogo has great share tools to make this easier!
Thank you all from the bottom of my heart!

story:
Hello!

My name is TheRoguez and I'm a freelance cartoon and animal artist! I primarily draw cute canines and colorful psychedelics - this campaign will be a mix of the two. I have five pin designs I want to make for you all, and this will help me fund them! 

These five designs feature coyotes with various themes. Originally I designed only the coyotes holding coffee mugs, but after a lot of positive feedback I decided to add two more designs to be finished - a coyote embracing a cactus, and a coyote with a crow in its mouth. The campaign will alternate between unlocking a coffee themed pin, or a more psychedelic themed pin. If we can reach the funding goal, I'll even continue to finish more pins as stretch goals! 

Each pin will be:

  • Made from hard enamel
  • 2" long
  • Outlined and backed in gold metal

However there will not be backing cards unless the campaign is fully funded! Each design should take about a month to produce, and expected to ship in January or February 2020.

The campaign will be run with flexible funding, rounded up to the next unlockable pin. For example, if one pin is fully funded but we only get halfway to unlocking the next pin, I'll be paying the rest to reach that goal. This also means that if the campaign "fails" and we don't unlock every pin, Indiegogo will still charge you and I will still use the funds to pay for what's been unlocked (and the closest one to being unlocked). 


The pins will be unlocked in this order and updated as we reach goals!









 



When you pledge for a certain number of pins, you get to pick which design you want out of the unlocked designs. This means that if you pledge for one pin, and only one or two are unlocked, you get to pick from those - but if all five pins are unlocked, you can pick any of them! If we reach the stretch goals, you'll also get to pick from those designs, and new perks will be added to purchase more than 5 pins!

 

Funds Breakdown

The cost to produce 50 pins of one design will be about $300, and to ship each of those pins in the US, it will be an additional $150 (and more so for international shipping). I've priced the initial pin at $500, and each pin following at $450. 

 

Risks and Rewards

This is my first crowdfunded campaign, but not my first time selling merchandise! I've made and sold comic books for years in the past, as well as bandannas, prints, and more, and am soon planning on launching another campaign for a plushie. Any problems or delays that may come up during this campaign will be transparent, and I will notify you and work through them to get your rewards to you. 


Thank you for supporting me! Your help will allow me to make more designs and merchandise like these in the future, and I can't wait to share them with you!

story:
MEDIALAB is:

  • a FREE art educational program that has been planting the seeds for social change through art practices for 10 years now.
  • an open studio for young artists and artistic youth in Armenia․

MEDIALAB

  • provides students with technical and theoretical knowledge in various disciplines of art, including photography, video-making, creative writing, exposition work, etc.
  • develops critical thinking and artistic skills in youth artists, as well as the cultivation of a personal art style.

What’s else?  
MEDIALAB is a unique opportunity for artistic youth to:

  • implement individual projects
  • receive free consultation and technical support
  • become a part of local and international artistic networks and create new collaborations in the field.

Isn’t this all a young artist needs while taking first steps in the field?

MEDIALAB students during “Camera Operating Skills” workshop

________

WHO RUNS THE PROGRAM? 

We are a group of friends that consists of artists and experts who have art experience in various settings: through outdated academic art education, alternative art educational practices, and even self-education. With all of our combined experience, we were inspired to establish a unique program that implements the best methods from each type of education in order to create new opportunities for the younger generation.

At the heart of the program is our vision of how education should be and we have created an environment that allows this vision to become a reality. We have designed a program that inspires students to enjoy art, learn its social impact and importance, and encourages them to become active members of the art community and in society as a whole. We truly believe that being an artist is not only about having technical skills, but first of all about having the ability to think outside the box—to be daring enough to question everyday boundaries. MEDIALAB is an environment where these potentials, mental skills, and practices are stimulated and strengthened.

________

Our history and experience

We started 10 years ago as a video-editing and photo shooting workshop, and 5 years later we started organizing a semi-annual program which provided both technical and theoretical knowledge to artists and amateurs.

Throughout these 10 years we have established the foundation of our future school by:

  • continually expanding and elaborating on our list of workshops, most of which are not available in any other art educational institution in Armenia.
  • developing unique teaching methods and curricula for our programs.
  • procuring a good reputation and possessing a significant role in the field of art education in Armenia.
  • developing a large network of local and international partners which includes the expanding list of the best young specialists and instructors, experts and consultants, partner institutions, etc.
  • creating a technically well-equipped workshop and laboratory, together with a professional library, all which provide our students with the necessary resources and environment for their professional growth.
  • reaching a high level of competitiveness, typically receiving 10 applications per place–among them students and alumni from all types of artistic and cultural institutions.
  • preparing and encouraging our students to get involved and established in different art fields in Armenia, by creating artistic groups and institutions, becoming employees and members of different art institutions, developing individual projects, etc.

These 10 years have not been without challenges. We have experienced various crises and transformations. However, unlike many similar schools which have stopped operating because of obstacles, we were the only organization that managed to survive and even thrive. We have made it to where we are, having a $0 budget for operations for several years—friendship and enthusiasm being the main and only capital of the project.

And now, with 10 years of experience—with our success and growing popularity—we aspire to evolve and expand even further so that we can BETTER SERVE & OFFER MORE to our community.

Being a non profit initiative, we rely on your donation to make it happen.

________

Please consider donating if:

- you believe in free alternative art education in the new Armenia.
- you would like to contribute to the modernization of Armenian society and artistic youth.

By donating to MEDIALAB your support will have a
far-reaching effect on building a new future.

________

How to Help & What You Get

The raised prices are for a variety of purposes. Look into the project budget here for a full and detailed description of our expenses.

You can help us by:
1. purchasing the various products of our activities

  • postcards with the creative images of our student’s works
  • a nice fabric bag of our library and a useful bookmark
  • one or more of our publications (please just note that most of them are in Armenian)

2. choosing to support specific activities or needs (or supporting the initiative in general)

  • sponsoring the publication of our textbook
  • supporting a rented space
  • equipment purchase, etc

3. spreading the word

  • among the international art community
  • among your friends and family
  • sharing events on social media

Any help is appreciated and welcomed.

__
PERKS

Choose your perk(s)!

$7 - A coffee with the MEDIALAB team
Do you love coffee and art?
You can save your morning or lunchtime coffee budget for MEDIALAB and in return we’ll invite you for a cup of coffee and office-made cookies at any time in our comfortable space. You’ll leave our space feeling relaxed yet energised!

$15 - A Set of Postcards
A set of creative postcards with the best photograms and photographs by our students! We’ve enjoyed the process of creating them, you’ll enjoy the result! Who knows, having these postcards, one day you may be the owner of a work of a well-known artist. You can even ask for signed copies.

$25 - A book and bookmarks!
Are you a book-lover? Choose this perk and get one of our most popular publications, Հանրային ոլորտի և հասարակայնության միջև (Between The Public Sphere and Öffentlichkeit), as well as two bookmarks from the Focus library. Please note that the book is in Armenian. Not familiar with the book? Find out more here.

$35 - A Soviet Modernism Poster!
Take one of the 5 posters designed by Nvard Yerkanian with a special Price for Medialab Supporters. The posters are part of a series of “Soviet Modernist Architecture in Armenia” continuous project, which is an ode to the architectural heritage that is either lost or unfairly undervalued. There are 3 A2 (60x60cm) choices available,
- Sevan Writers' Resort by architect Gevorg Kochar, 1960s.
- Cinema Rossiya, Yerevan, Armenia by architects Spartak Khachikyan, Hrachik Poghosyan, and Artur Tarkhanyan, 1975.
- Zvartnots Airport by architects Levon Cherkezyan, Spartak Khachikyan, Artur Tarkhanyan, and Zhorzh Shekhlyan, designed in 1975.

$55 - A Book Lover!
Take this perk and receive two publications by Focus and/or it’s partners and choose either (1) a solid fabric bag from our library or (2) another publication for FREE. All these publications are unique and focus on art or related disciplines. They are both a joy to read and also inspire many thought-provoking questions to ponder. Find the list below.
Հանրային ոլորտի և հասարակայնության միջև (Between The Public Sphere and Öffentlichkeit),
Spaces: Cultural Public Sphere in Armenia, Moldova and Ukraine 
Ժակ Ռանսիեր «Անգետ Ուսուցիչը»
Քաղաքատնտեսություն

$100 - Soviet Modernism Posters' Set 
Get a set of these beautiful posters with a Special Price for Medialab Supporters. Three masterpieces of Armenian Soviet Modernist architecture on your wall by Nvard Yerkanian within the series of “Soviet Modernist Architecture in Armenia” project. This project is an ode to the architectural heritage that is either lost, or unfairly undervalued. The Set includes 3 A2 (or 60x60cm) size posters (no frames).
- Sevan Writers' Resort by architect Gevorg Kochar, 1960s.
- Cinema Rossiya, Yerevan, Armenia by architects Spartak Khachikyan, Hrachik Poghosyan, and Artur Tarkhanyan, 1975.
- Zvartnots Airport by architects Levon Cherkezyan, Spartak Khachikyan, Artur Tarkhanyan, and Zhorzh Shekhlyan, designed in 1975.
 

__
Sponsorships
 

$200 Early Bird's Perk!
The first two supporters of the trainer’s course will receive a copy of a sourcebook on photography “Inquiries into Photography“ (Lուսանկարչության հարցեր. տեսություն եւ տեխնիկա) designed by our trainers Karin Grigoryan and Vahe Budumyan . If you study or have an interest in photography, this is a rare chance to enjoy the publication in Armenian. 


$200 SUPPORT ONE OF OUR TRAINERS COURSE. - Our experts and trainers work hard and we would like to show our appreciation. Some of our trainers have worked as volunteers all these years. Some have asked only for a small, insignificant payment for their participation and valuable work. However, we would like to minimise such practices in the future so help support our trainers and experts so that they can be rewarded for their work. We also need some honorariums for invited trainers and experts, both from abroad and locally. Choose this perk and support one of
our trainers course.
Meet our trainers:

Elena Aydinyan, art critique, editor of Critical Review online journal,  teacher of several subjects related to history and theory of modern and contemporary art as well as to art historiography at the State Academy of Fine Arts of Armenia
Course: Contemporary Art History
Ashot Boyajyan, cameramen
Course: Camera Operating skills
Vahe Budumyan, artist, co-founder of Focus Art NGO, deputy ministry of culture
Course: Analogue and Digital Photography 
Nora Galfayan, freelance graphic designer, co-founder of Focus art NGO
Course: Graphic Design Basics
Karin Grigoryan, translator, researcher in photography
Course: Theory and History of Photography, Image Reading
Anna Davtian, writer, photographer, translator, teacher of Creative Writing at TUMO center for creative technologies
Course: Creative Writing
Vardan Harutyunyan, sound artist
Course: Sound Art
Davit Stepanyan, director, co-founder and member of editorial board of Political Discourse online think-tank, co-founder of Focus art NGO
Course: History and Theory of Montaj
Gor Yengoyan, artist, director of visual Arts department at ACCEA
Course: Exhibition making


$446 - One month SPACE rent.
Our most crucial and urgent need is a larger space to support our growing number of students and friends.  Choose the space perk and support our one (or more) month rent.

$939 - EQUIPMENT for our technical lab.
We currently have well-equipped technical labs, but we still lack certain items that could make our workshops even better and more effective. For example, a film scanner, a film camera, and a monitor (as the one we have used for the past 7 years has become damaged recently). Choose the equipment perk and help us buy equipment that our students have been eager to have.

$2098  - TEXTBOOK for “history and theory on Montaj” classes
 One of the most important aspects of a successful school is content. For years, we have been creating this content through the establishment of a professional multilingual library—by translating as well as creating different articles in Armenian. Two years ago, our trainers produced a textbook on photography which has had great popularity so far. Now we have been working on a book on the topic of “Ontology and History of Cinema” that will become a part of our “History and Theory on Montaj” classes. Some of the texts have already been translated and with your help, we will be able to finalise and publish it. Choose this perk not only to support the publication, but to have your major impact on the development of the field of cinema. Be the first to get 5 issues of the publication with your name on it.

You also have the option of becoming a yearly sponsor of the school.
Or if your aspiration is beyond the suggested perks and sponsorships, please email us at medialab@focus.org.am to discuss other ways to collaborate. We will be happy to get in touch.

________​

The Impact

This project’s impact is two-fold.
1. It has an immense impact on students! It helps amazing, bright youth find their niche in the arts.
Unfortunately, art is still considered to be a leisure or a hobby as opposed to a valid profession in Armenia. Society (including most of the parents of our students) are not keen to invest in art education. They believe that it is not a serious profession and that people cannot make a living through a profession in the arts. We disprove these stereotypes and ideas. We instill in students critical thinking skills, the key to creativity and self-education, and open up opportunities in the field for them, all so that they can further realize their skills and potential.



Our Alumni and Impact

Our alumni become active members in the field. They apply their skills and knowledge within different fields of art—such as photography, directing, performance art, sound art, curating, art management, cultural journalism, as well as the difficult work of cultural translating, “infecting” others with their enthusiasm and crazy ideas.

Some of the recent achievements made by alumni:
1. In 2017 our alumni Viktor Zatikyan, Vazgen Harutyunyan, Greta Harutyunyan, and Sona Mnatsakanyan got involved with the analogue photo laboratorium BOX, established by Viktor Zatikyan and his friend. The Box has since become a unique space for students and amateurs not only to learn and practice analogue photo printing, but to organise film screenings, workshops, projects etc. More about the BOX here.

2. 6 Medialab students (Mariam Aleksanyan, Arpi Hovakimyan, Sirarpy Chibukhchyan, Lusine Mkrtchyan, Hripsime Dayan, Anet Bilyan) established an art collective RED which has since developed a number of art projects and participated in the art festivals, exhibitions and individual projects. Find more about RED here.

3. Our alumna Hripsime Dayan, besides her artistic career, has committed herself to translating. She recently published a book with her translations of texts and interviews by Pier Burdeau and Jean Baudrillard. More about the book here

4. Our alumna Arpi Balyan has become a co-founder of Fem Library, a unique feminist initiative that aims to create a safe space for feminist education, knowledge building and sharing, organising and resistance.

5. Some of our alumni are involved in (Cultural) Journalism at media platforms such as Hetq.am, civilnet.am, media.am, ankakh.am, etc.

6. Our alumna Lilith Khandakaryan has been a part of the MEDIALAB coordination team for two years now. She is also engaged in other art project as a cultural manager and coordinator.
7. Lilith in a way continues a tradition established by Vahe Budumyan. Vahe is a former student of MEDIALAB who took up project coordination in 2011 and has since been inspiring future students to produce greater works. Currently Vahe Budumyan is the Deputy Minister of Culture of Armenia, which is a great pride and honor for us.

We could make this list longer, but in short, it is all about how our students become our partners, enriching the sphere each year with fresh ideas and projects. This is the greatest indication of our impact.   
 

MEDIALAB also indirectly benefits society as a whole.

Our alumni are among the most progressive youth in Armenia, who have innovative ideas and diversity; as a result, they become active proponents of change. One should never ignore the powerful role of creativity and the arts in facilitating social and cultural progress.

________

Risks & Challenges

You may ask whether funding an Art School in Armenia today is a crazy idea.
We say, Yes, it is, but has it ever been easy?
(Contemporary) Art Education has never been a popular topic, neither for our government nor for various donors and funds. We always had to struggle to transform our ideas into reality and we have been persistent enough to survive and even grow within these harsh conditions.  We have learned to be flexible, work with various crises, and manage our limited resources, all this to create the best products possible.
We have gained a large amount of experience, a wide network of friends and partners, along with the potential and enthusiasm to grow and move even further forward.
 

We believe that  it is from little acorns that great oaks grow!
We have fertilized the soil and with your support, we’ll grow even higher.
 

SUPPORT!  HELP US GROW!

There are 3 A2 (60x60cm) choices available,- Sevan Writers' Resort by architect Gevorg Kochar, 1960s.- Cinema Rossiya, Yerevan, Armenia by architects Spartak Khachikyan, Hrachik Poghosyan, and Artur Tarkhanyan, 1975.- Zvartnots Airport by architects Levon Cherkezyan, Spartak Khachikyan, Artur Tarkhanyan, and Zhorzh Shekhlyan, designed in 1975.$55 - A Book Lover!Take this perk and receive two publications by Focus and/or it’s partners and choose either (1) a solid fabric bag from our library or (2) another publication for FREE. All these publications are unique and focus on art or related disciplines. They are both a joy to read and also inspire many thought-provoking questions to ponder. Find the list below.Հանրային ոլորտի և հասարակայնության միջև (Between The Public Sphere and Öffentlichkeit),Spaces: Cultural Public Sphere in Armenia, Moldova and Ukraine Ժակ Ռանսիեր «Անգետ Ուսուցիչը»Քաղաքատնտեսություն$100 - Soviet Modernism Posters' Set Get a set of these beautiful posters with a Special Price for Medialab Supporters. Three masterpieces of Armenian Soviet Modernist architecture on your wall by Nvard Yerkanian within the series of “Soviet Modernist Architecture in Armenia” project. This project is an ode to the architectural heritage that is either lost, or unfairly undervalued. The Set includes 3 A2 (or 60x60cm) size posters (no frames).- Sevan Writers' Resort by architect Gevorg Kochar, 1960s.- Cinema Rossiya, Yerevan, Armenia by architects Spartak Khachikyan, Hrachik Poghosyan, and Artur Tarkhanyan, 1975.- Zvartnots Airport by architects Levon Cherkezyan, Spartak Khachikyan, Artur Tarkhanyan, and Zhorzh Shekhlyan, designed in 1975. __Sponsorships $200 Early Bird's Perk!The first two supporters of the trainer’s course will receive a copy of a sourcebook on photography “Inquiries into Photography“ (Lուսանկարչության հարցեր. տեսություն եւ տեխնիկա) designed by our trainers Karin Grigoryan and Vahe Budumyan . If you study or have an interest in photography, this is a rare chance to enjoy the publication in Armenian. $200 SUPPORT ONE OF OUR TRAINERS COURSE. - Our experts and trainers work hard and we would like to show our appreciation. Some of our trainers have worked as volunteers all these years. Some have asked only for a small, insignificant payment for their participation and valuable work. However, we would like to minimise such practices in the future so help support our trainers and experts so that they can be rewarded for their work. We also need some honorariums for invited trainers and experts, both from abroad and locally. Choose this perk and support one ofour trainers course.Meet our trainers:Elena Aydinyan, art critique, editor of Critical Review online journal,  teacher of several subjects related to history and theory of modern and contemporary art as well as to art historiography at the State Academy of Fine Arts of ArmeniaCourse: Contemporary Art HistoryAshot Boyajyan, cameramenCourse: Camera Operating skillsVahe Budumyan, artist, co-founder of Focus Art NGO, deputy ministry of cultureCourse: Analogue and Digital Photography Nora Galfayan, freelance graphic designer, co-founder of Focus art NGOCourse: Graphic Design BasicsKarin Grigoryan, translator, researcher in photographyCourse: Theory and History of Photography, Image ReadingAnna Davtian, writer, photographer, translator, teacher of Creative Writing at TUMO center for creative technologiesCourse: Creative WritingVardan Harutyunyan, sound artistCourse: Sound ArtDavit Stepanyan, director, co-founder and member of editorial board of Political Discourse online think-tank, co-founder of Focus art NGOCourse: History and Theory of MontajGor Yengoyan, artist, director of visual Arts department at ACCEACourse: Exhibition making$446 - One month SPACE rent.Our most crucial and urgent need is a larger space to support our growing number of students and friends.  Choose the space perk and support our one (or more) month rent.$939 - EQUIPMENT for our technical lab.We currently have well-equipped technical labs, but we still lack certain items that could make our workshops even better and more effective. For example, a film scanner, a film camera, and a monitor (as the one we have used for the past 7 years has become damaged recently). Choose the equipment perk and help us buy equipment that our students have been eager to have.$2098  - TEXTBOOK for “history and theory on Montaj” classes One of the most important aspects of a successful school is content. For years, we have been creating this content through the establishment of a professional multilingual library—by translating as well as creating different articles in Armenian. Two years ago, our trainers produced a textbook on photography which has had great popularity so far. Now we have been working on a book on the topic of “Ontology and History of Cinema” that will become a part of our “History and Theory on Montaj” classes. Some of the texts have already been translated and with your help, we will be able to finalise and publish it. Choose this perk not only to support the publication, but to have your major impact on the development of the field of cinema. Be the first to get 5 issues of the publication with your name on it.You also have the option of becoming a yearly sponsor of the school.Or if your aspiration is beyond the suggested perks and sponsorships, please email us at medialab@focus.org.am to discuss other ways to collaborate. We will be happy to get in touch.________​The ImpactThis project’s impact is two-fold.1. It has an immense impact on students! It helps amazing, bright youth find their niche in the arts.Unfortunately, art is still considered to be a leisure or a hobby as opposed to a valid profession in Armenia. Society (including most of the parents of our students) are not keen to invest in art education. They believe that it is not a serious profession and that people cannot make a living through a profession in the arts. We disprove these stereotypes and ideas. We instill in students critical thinking skills, the key to creativity and self-education, and open up opportunities in the field for them, all so that they can further realize their skills and potential.
Our Alumni and ImpactOur alumni become active members in the field. They apply their skills and knowledge within different fields of art—such as photography, directing, performance art, sound art, curating, art management, cultural journalism, as well as the difficult work of cultural translating, “infecting” others with their enthusiasm and crazy ideas.Some of the recent achievements made by alumni:1. In 2017 our alumni Viktor Zatikyan, Vazgen Harutyunyan, Greta Harutyunyan, and Sona Mnatsakanyan got involved with the analogue photo laboratorium BOX, established by Viktor Zatikyan and his friend. The Box has since become a unique space for students and amateurs not only to learn and practice analogue photo printing, but to organise film screenings, workshops, projects etc. More about the BOX here.2. 6 Medialab students (Mariam Aleksanyan, Arpi Hovakimyan, Sirarpy Chibukhchyan, Lusine Mkrtchyan, Hripsime Dayan, Anet Bilyan) established an art collective RED which has since developed a number of art projects and participated in the art festivals, exhibitions and individual projects. Find more about RED here.3. Our alumna Hripsime Dayan, besides her artistic career, has committed herself to translating. She recently published a book with her translations of texts and interviews by Pier Burdeau and Jean Baudrillard. More about the book here4. Our alumna Arpi Balyan has become a co-founder of Fem Library, a unique feminist initiative that aims to create a safe space for feminist education, knowledge building and sharing, organising and resistance.5. Some of our alumni are involved in (Cultural) Journalism at media platforms such as Hetq.am, civilnet.am, media.am, ankakh.am, etc.6. Our alumna Lilith Khandakaryan has been a part of the MEDIALAB coordination team for two years now. She is also engaged in other art project as a cultural manager and coordinator.7. Lilith in a way continues a tradition established by Vahe Budumyan. Vahe is a former student of MEDIALAB who took up project coordination in 2011 and has since been inspiring future students to produce greater works. Currently Vahe Budumyan is the Deputy Minister of Culture of Armenia, which is a great pride and honor for us.We could make this list longer, but in short, it is all about how our students become our partners, enriching the sphere each year with fresh ideas and projects. This is the greatest indication of our impact.    MEDIALAB also indirectly benefits society as a whole.Our alumni are among the most progressive youth in Armenia, who have innovative ideas and diversity; as a result, they become active proponents of change. One should never ignore the powerful role of creativity and the arts in facilitating social and cultural progress.________Risks & ChallengesYou may ask whether funding an Art School in Armenia today is a crazy idea.We say, Yes, it is, but has it ever been easy?(Contemporary) Art Education has never been a popular topic, neither for our government nor for various donors and funds. We always had to struggle to transform our ideas into reality and we have been persistent enough to survive and even grow within these harsh conditions.  We have learned to be flexible, work with various crises, and manage our limited resources, all this to create the best products possible.We have gained a large amount of experience, a wide network of friends and partners, along with the potential and enthusiasm to grow and move even further forward. We believe that  it is from little acorns that great oaks grow!We have fertilized the soil and with your support, we’ll grow even higher. SUPPORT!  HELP US GROW!

story:
Short Summary

Hello - My name is Dave Richardson. I'm a full time professional artist. My work can be seen in many galleries in the U.S as well as abroad. You can view more of my work online at: www.daverichardsonart.com

Recently, I've made the jump to start my own online company for clothing and jewelry, Dark Sails. It's my mission to produce high quality, unique handcrafted jewelry and heavy hitting imagery for t-shirts, hoodies, hats, etc... I've assembled a team of amazing artists to help me get these designs executes on on to the bodies of the supporters of Dark Sails. We've been working around the clock for 2 months now to make this happen. My good friend and brilliant artist Clive Barker and his crew have even offered some illustrations for t-shirts. I'm very excited to get this ship sailing! 

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for a small contribution from you to help fund this journey. The money will primarily be going to the Ecommerce website where you will be able to click and buy with ease. My web designer has assured me this will take some time and money but will be well worth it. Once the site is up (www.darksails.net) all the beautiful art we've been working on will be available at very reasonable prices. The leftover money will go to silkscreen set-up, clothing, foundry bill for casting the white bronze, and photography. The Ecommerce website is essential for the success of Dark Sails so please help me make this happen. PERK: If you contribute $25 or more you will receive a Dark Sails wearable medallion! 


DARKS SAILS IS ART FOR THE WARDROBE: a brief write-up

Until recently, the work of professional artist Dave Richardson could only be seen in galleries in the United States and abroad. But now that he’s started Dark Sails, his own online company for clothing and jewelry, his art can be seen on the human canvas. Clothing is known for making a statement, but when artist and horror writer Clive Barker is one of the contributors, future clients can expect t-shirts that will be as creative as they may be creepy. Richardson’s sartorial version of “Welcome to My Nightmare” is now an Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign that’s seeking $2500 in order to provide his venture with an online e-commerce website.

Richardson and his team of artists have been working around the clock for two months to make the dream a reality. Keep in mind, however, that for Richardson’s work, a good dream is nightmare imagery in tangible form. “It’s my mission to produce high-quality, unique, handcrafted jewelry and heavy-hitting imagery for t-shirts, hoodies, hats, etc.,” Richardson says. Richardson, a well known postmodern sculptor whose works cover the spectrum of fantasy, dark art, mystical art, and art nouveau, as well as the distinct flavor of the macabre, has a knack for transforming his sculpture into surreal depiction. Fans of the imagery who study his artwork are going to eagerly anticipate the transition from art that is seen to the art that is worn. Richardson’s advice to his art fans is to “sit back and leave your reality behind, step into the world of light and dark through form and sculpture.”

Once the e-commerce website is set up and working, customers will be able to click and buy with ease. The time and money this will cost are well worth it. Once the site is up, all the art that Richardson and crew have been working on will be available at reasonable prices. Leftover crowdfunding funds will pay for the silkscreen set-up, the clothing, the foundry bill for the casting of the white bronze, and photography.

Richardson’s artistry has been able to transcend media for much of his professional career. He began drawing and sculpting at a young age, and early on, he was captivated by the creatures of the unknown and unseen. It was when he was in high school, when he began working in art studios around his home town, that he became immersed in all aspects of sculpture and the lost wax process. Success followed skill and before long he and his work were showing up in publications such as Amazing Figure Modeler Magazine, Churn, Gothic Beauty Magazine, and he was featured on Keith Wigdor Presents Surrealism Now.


Artistic exploration led him to work in all areas of art including sculpting, molding, casting, painting, design, metal fabrication, welding/chasing, and woodworking. With that in mind, it’s small wonder that he has since turned to jewelry and clothing. His artwork can be seen in public and private collections in his native United States but also in Canada, England, Russia, Hong Kong and Australia.

The visual appeal of his work, which bodes well for his clothing and jewelry, arises from his ability to delve deep into his unconsciousness in order to unearth deep-seated emotions and thoughts, summoning them to the surface of reality where they acquire permanence and life back on Earth. This powerful evocation of art has earned him attention not only from horror writer Clive Barker, an artist as well as a writer who will contribute illustrations for the t-shirts, but also from film director Guillermo Del Toro. His work with celebrities has also brought him into contact with the Hell’s Angels motorcycle group. The diversity of his circle of admirers demonstrates the versatility of his message and the manner in which his embrace of the life-death-rebirth cycle translates easily into other perspectives.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us raise the sails by supporting online with 

Instagram @dark_sails 

Facebook @Dark Sails

Twitter @dark_sails

Help spread the word!

Thanks-

                Dave Richardson 

               www.daverichardsonart.com

               www.darksails.net

story:
My name is Ratri.

I was born in Jakarta but grew up in America and Canada. My mother was an etch artist and my father is an ethnomusicologist, from their mannerisms I learned  everyone has their own extension of themselves. For me its painting. 

Moving back to Indonesia, it has become evident to me of the social, environmental, economic and political stresses this country faces.  But if art is used correctly, it can be a powerful force to help drive us in the right direction. After my studies, I would like to return to this country and strengthen the connection of our diverse web of artists and create ways of bettering our livelihoods as a unit.

At the moment I am on a pursuit to continue my arts education in Europe and have recently been accepted to an artist in residence program at TAKT Academy, Berlin. Afterwards I plan on continuing to university in the fall of 2016.

And to be able to reach this long time dream of mine, I need help from you and other supporters!


Where are your contributions going?

A year ago my mother passed from ovarian cancer and her medical bills have left my family financially unstable and due to the incredible economic differences between  Germany and Indonesia, I need help raising $5000 to fund myself toBerlin. The contributions will directly go to:
- the program
- living expenses
- visa applications
The restt will go directly into my university savings. I hope to attend the University of Arts, Bremen in fall, where they have an outstanding BA Fine Arts program for international students.  

Nature Be So Rad is the name of my fundraising exhibition open October 30th 2015 at Room4Dessert Ubud, Bali. A showcase of my work from the last 4 years, following the satirical relationship between nature and human. 

Remember to check out the gallery! 

SO FAR... what I've been doing to raise funding


I have been doing odd art jobs around Indonesia.
Live painting at music festivals such as Bali Spirit Festival 2014 and 2015 as a way to promote myself as an artist. I even got to perform with Kuno Kini in the Eco Camp Festival 2015, which is a nationally recognized band in Indonesia!
I also worked as a freelance muralist here and there, doing personal home décor or large scale murals. 

I’m ready to progress even further and being in Berlin, one the most progressive contemporary arts scene in the world, will be a great first step to becoming a serious visual artist.

Check out http://www.radhati.tumblr.com to see my art! 


Other ways you can help me!
If you’d like to help please tell people about me and what I aspire to do! Check out my portfolio on tumblr and share this Indiegogo campaign on all types of social media. And of course come check out my work OCTOBER 30TH 2015 for my first exhibition at ROOM4DESERT in Ubud Bali. 

And if you or anyone you know have any cool ideas that could help me on my pursuits, or even if you'd like to chat further, feel free to contact me!

Email - arundhati.studio@gmail.com
Handphone # 082144895427
